PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Are your government's election promises to maintain the pension benchmark of at least 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and to continue to index the pension twice yearly core commitments, to use the Prime Minister's terminology—that is, promises you intend to keep? Was your spokeswoman telling the truth when she said yesterday, `The government has ruled out fixing the pension by any different formula. It stays at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings'?

—In answering the senator's question, can I first of all say how shocked and appalled I am at the opposition's disgraceful use of elderly Australians in frightening them that somehow $54 is to be ripped off their pensions. They know full well that is not true. The Prime Minister has made it very clear over and over again, as have I, that our commitment to the elderly stays firm. The question asked by the senator is whether we will stick by those commitments and the answer is yes.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that answer, will Senator Newman now give an assurance that the undertaking she has just given will apply for the forward estimate period in total?

—The question concerns the period of the forward estimates, but I wonder whether the senator has a longer term view than most of us. I am not prepared to answer the question into infinity. We are not going to allow the opposition to continue to frighten elderly Australians. That commitment stands regardless.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the New Zealand House of Representatives Labour Committee led by the Chairman, Mr Max Bradford MP. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and hope that your visit will be productive and enjoyable.

—My question is to Senator Short. Can the Assistant Treasurer confirm that the National Commission of Audit supported the government's election promise to establish a charter of budget honesty which would ensure that truthful budget forecasts are released before general elections of the parliament? What does this recommendation say about the failed Keating‐Beazley government's record of budget accountability? Will the minister reconfirm that the government intends to honour this important election promise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for his question. I am pleased to note that the Commission of Audit does support the government's policy for a charter of budget honesty. In particular, it supports updated budget forecasts being released before general elections in a way that will keep governments honest, which is something the former Labor government was never prepared to do. The Commission of Audit stresses that the frequency of fiscal reporting has a strong bearing on the extent to which such reporting increases the pressure on governments to act responsibly. We agree entirely with this.

ANSWER.PARA: It is particularly important that the public has access to up‐to‐date information about the fiscal outlook during election campaigns. We all know the record of the Keating‐Beazley government in that regard. They did not believe in budget honesty. They refused time and time again to release updated fiscal forecasts. If I understand it correctly, the now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, has confirmed that position since the budget.

BREAK.PARA: The previous government put their narrow political interests above those of the Australian people. When the forecasts were finally released two days after the election—and they were available to the then government before the election—they revealed Mr Beazley's $8 billion black hole. Before the election, we said that our charter of budget honesty would ensure that governments publish up‐to‐date economic and fiscal forecasts before general elections. Publishing updated forecasts is not only good in terms of fostering fiscal responsibility; it is good for democracy all round.

I am very happy to reconfirm the government's commitment to these important reforms. We are very pleased that the independent Commission of Audit supports our position. The Commission of Audit also recommends that legislation be introduced to give effect to budget honesty and that the mid‐year reviews show updated forward estimates. The government supports these recommendations as well. The shadow Treasurer, Mr Evans, made some interesting remarks about these matters on Friday night on ABC television when he said:

. . . the problem around the end of last year or the first few weeks of this year was that there was no more reliable data that would give any better an estimate as to what's going to happen next year than what we'd said last August.
First of all, the shadow Treasurer got the date wrong. The budget was handed down in May of last year. Given that it was their last budget, I am surprised that Labor cannot get the month right.

Let me make it clear that that was not a mere slip of the tongue by the shadow Treasurer. Rather, it revealed a disturbing ignorance of how much additional economic information was around in the period leading up to the election. Because, at the time of the May budget last year, the former government and the Treasury had access only to the December 1994 national accounts. But by early this year, well before the election, the September 1995 national accounts were available. In other words, since the budget was brought down last year, Labor had access to three‐quarters more economic information by the time the election was called. Of course, they had estimates of significant policy changes made subsequent to the budget. Yet the shadow Treasurer last week said that there was no more reliable information available before the election, and that of course was nonsense. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, can you explain why the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance suggested that the National Commission of Audit advise the government on the appropriateness of the current benchmark for setting the pension? Were you, as the Minister for Social Security, consulted by these ministers before the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury wrote to the National Commission of Audit on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that previous governments have looked over the years at the long-term consequences for the nation of the age pension and how it should be assessed. This is the situation for any government that is responsible for looking at long-term policy development. The fact remains that this is an independent report to government looking to the medium‐ and long-term direction of policy and administration. There are a number of benchmarks that could be established.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems to me that one of the things the opposition is not prepared to recognise is the fact that the regular indexation of pensions was introduced by the Fraser coalition government during the late seventies. So why should we be in any way wanting to walk away from a fair go for elderly Australians? The Whitlam government did not introduce that; it was the Fraser government.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a long way of saying you never had a clue.
—Order! There are too many interjections. Senator Newman has the call.

—I know that those opposite are feeling pretty desperate being in opposition. They have to try to run with any hare that comes. If frightening old people is part of their game plan, then they are going to be thrashed and thrashed and thrashed. I have nothing to add other than that a responsible government of whatever colour should be looking to the future of national expenditure. That is what is happening currently, and I hope it will happen in the future. If the lot on the other side of the chamber were ever to get into government again, we would be back in the same position we are now: needing a commission of audit so that the taxpayers of Australia would know how they were placed.

—Mr President, on a supplementary question: I ask Senator Newman if, as Minister for Social Security, she was consulted by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance on this matter. I also ask: why did the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury write to the National Commission of Audit on 16 April saying that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance had met; that they had suggested the current policy of benchmarking the age pension level against 25 per cent of average weekly earnings be considered by the Commission of Audit; and that they wanted the Commission of Audit to examine which particular measure of average weekly earnings was the most appropriate? Why were you not consulted on these matters?
—I have made it clear in previous questions with these sorts of fishing expeditions that I am not going to help the opposition in wanting to know what is going on within the government.
—Were you consulted?

—I have told you that you will not be trying these fishing expeditions with any success. Mr President, this fellow over here is a very slow learner. Can I tell him again once and for all that this government will not be discussing the innermost workings of government anymore than your government chose to do so when we were in opposition.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. The minister would be aware of the comments made by Telstra's chief executive, Mr Frank Blount, supportive of the government's initiative to partially privatise Telstra. Is Mr Blount correct in stating that a partially privatised Telstra will offer consumers a better quality of service? Do these comments add to the growing body of evidence that a partially privatised Telstra is good for customers, is good for Telstra, is good for the environment and is good for Australia but is not good for the ideologically fixated mob on the other side?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Mr Blount's comments were of great interest to all thinking Australians, because what Mr Blount did was effectively spell out on behalf of the board—in other words, on behalf of the entire company—what he thought was in its best interests. He went through I thought in very careful detail five key advantages which he said flowed from privatisation. The first was that Telstra would be accountable to its shareholders on a daily basis. It certainly isn't at the moment. As we know, the only shareholder it had prior to 2 March was Paul Keating. He did what he liked and ran rampant over the outfit.

ANSWER.PARA: That is precisely what Mr Blount's second point was: that public ownership has the potential to distract management from maximising the value of the business and to reward good politics rather than commercial excellence. So that is precisely what Mr Blount was saying should not happen and would not happen under a privatised Telstra. He also said that it is important to have regulatory and policy transparency. In other words, he wants to avoid that conflict of interest. He also wants to lower Telstra's overall cost of capital. Again, he makes it clear that privatisation would achieve that.

Finally, he said incentive schemes as announced by the government in its privatisation policy will give a new edge to the motivation of all Telstra's people. He says that competition is vitally important and that, if you could have only one, you would go for competition but, if you can have both, you ought to have it and the result will be better outcomes over all. In other words, Mr Blount is making it quite clear that Australia has the opportunity of having the best of all worlds if it goes down the path of sensible reform, as has the rest of the world. And can I add to that long and growing list of countries that have now gone down the privatisation path. I have seen a note that tells me that Kuwait has raised more than a billion dollars by selling stakes in its state firms and is leading its Gulf Arab neighbours in privatisation.

I do not know where you can go, Senator Kernot. You can run but you cannot hide. No other country is locked in the technology time warp you would have Australia in. There is no expert in the world who cannot see the virtues of privatisation. All Mr Blount was doing, I thought in a very measured and calm way, was pointing out the overwhelming benefits to Telstra, to consumers and to the community.
For those who express doom and gloom, as Bob Brown did the other day—he makes these statements that somehow we will all be worse off—what Mr Blount said was this:

I'd like to make an unequivocal undertaking: we will deliver a higher quality of service and better value to you as a partially privatised company, without diminishing or compromising Telstra's proud record of community service and community involvement ... I guarantee that what is best about Telstra ... will be enhanced and not devalued by this change in our ownership ...

Mr Blount also says the positives add up to a pretty persuasive case, especially in light of his own experience. He says that he has seen just about every possible permutation of the public-private monopoly‐competition matrix and that he has come to a simple conclusion.

Everyone else has come to the same simple conclusion too, and that is that the Democrats and others simply refuse to face the facts. I understand why the Chris Schachts and the Bob Collinses of this world are not interested because, as Bob Collins has told us many times, when you are in opposition—as he was in the Northern Territory before they booted him out—what you did was you absolutely clawed and scraped at everything; you said whatever was necessary to get you in. It had nothing to do with the truth. In other words, you were there to oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did I say that, you big fibber?
—We understand where they are coming from, but we just hope—
—You'll get a pimple on your tongue.

—I will pull it out for you, if you like. I hope that others who take a more considered view of the merits of the argument will take Mr Blount on the merits—not just say that somehow his integrity is on the line because he is being wheeled out. The fact is that he did not have to say anything if he did not want to, but he has obviously been very frustrated that the rest of the world is passing him by and that some people in this country simply insist on peddling lines that are utterly specious. (Time expired)

—I ask a supplementary question. Minister, have you found in your discussion with each and every one of the opposition parties that their collective minds are already made up on the sale of Telstra and that they will not countenance the evidence that may or may not be presented to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very significant that one of the arguments trotted out by both of the major opposition parties is that somehow this would not be in the best interests of rural consumers. The committee of inquiry to which they referred this bill—despite the fact that they have already decided to vote against it—has significantly downsized its number of meetings because there is so little concern in rural areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, the other day the National Farmers Federation conducted an inquiry which asked their constituency—in other words, people in rural Australia—whether or not they were in favour of privatisation. Overwhelmingly, by a two to one majority, they said yes. In other words, they do not have the concerns that Senator Kernot and others profess to have on their behalf.

Let rural Australia speak. The fact is they know it is in their best interests. They know they have been getting a very raw deal to date. They know the quality of service has been declining over the years. What they want is a fully competitive telecommunications environment without the sorts of compromises involved in public ownership. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, why does the Commission of Audit, in presenting its financial summary, treat superannuation payments but not pensions as an unfunded liability? Do you believe the definition of `unfunded liability' as used by the commission was correct? Will the government rule out retrospectivity as a solution to remedying the problems of unfunded liabilities identified by the commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —So far as superannuation arrangements in the public sector are concerned—I assume that is what Senator Sherry is talking about—they are unfunded liabilities. They are not provided for in the accounts of government on a year by year basis, whereas pensions are paid out of general revenue and are funded as they go.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to superannuation and other issues that go to the heart of arguably the most significant problem facing Australia—that is, lack of savings—the report makes some very useful comments about the role of superannuation and its performance in recent years, and makes some suggestions for the future. We will be looking at those recommendations and suggestions along with the ongoing review of superannuation that we are conducting and on which we will be announcing details in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, given the Prime Minister's description of reform of the unfair dismissal laws `the most important commitment' made to small business during the campaign, and given media reports of widespread backbench and ministerial unrest over the government's rejection of repeated Democrat offers to reform the unfair dismissal laws, I ask: will the government now separate that section from the rest of the workplace reform bill so that we may have these laws debated and reformed by the end of this week?

—I will give you a counter offer, Senator and that is why don't we debate the whole bill? Why don't we address some of the major problems that are facing this country? What we did say in the election was that we would reform the unfair dismissal laws together with the whole IR regime under Labor which had so centralised the system that it inhibited the flexibility necessary to encourage small business to employ and to grow. Why don't we debate it all? Why don't we get on with the job?
—Why not just do unfair dismissal?

—You could, Senator Kernot. If you so wished, you could split the bill clause by clause and debate each clause separately. But there does not seem to be any reason for us to suit your agenda and take out one part that you say you will support without your meeting your national responsibility of having to debate the whole bill—in other words, having to debate all of the reforms that we say are necessary to provide this country with a contemporary IR legislative regime. So my counter offer to you, Senator, is: why don't we get on with the job and debate the bill that has been presented to you by government?

—Minister, picking and choosing the bits you like is a bit like what you are doing today with the Commission of Audit report. On 28 March, when I met with the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith, he said to me that the reason I cannot do this, the reason we cannot split it, is that it is dependent on the rest of the bill. I have looked at the bill; I have checked that. There is no technical dependency; there is no connection. This part of the bill can stand alone. So I am asking you: why is the Prime Minister deliberately twisting the truth on this matter, particularly in the speech he gave in Sydney on Friday, and what is the real political reason that the government will not act now to deliver this reform by the end of the week? You are picking and choosing.

—I find this astonishing, Mr President; she criticises those who pick and choose but she comes into question time today, picks and chooses one particular part and says she will debate that part. I say to you, Senator: let us debate the reform package as a whole. We are happy to do this. We will go on sitting and do it, if you so wish. We will facilitate your requirements in that regard. But you cannot come into this place and pick the part that you like.
—Tell people the truth about why you are not debating it.

—The whole IR package and the principles behind the package were put to the electorate at the last election. The whole principle of the workplace agreements was spelt out. The community has had plenty of debate. The stakeholders have been debating it for a long period of time. We are quite happy to get on with the job and invite you to debate our piece of legislation, the piece of legislation that we as the government have put to you. The sooner you are ready to do that, the sooner we will all be better off. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the minister to the National Commission of Audit's recommendation that the government `urgently review the continuation of programs of assistance to business and to individuals at higher income levels against the principles for government involvement set out in chapter 2'. The commission is of the view that the non-means tested child-care cash rebate is one program which does not meet the principles for government involvement. Does the minister consider the non-means tested pension paid to blind people of age pension age to be another program that does not meet these principles? Can the minister confirm that the pension paid to blind people of age pension age will continue to be paid free of any income or assets test?

—Mr President, we can see what is going to come for days and days and weeks and weeks until they get tired of this toy and then run to another. If the Commission of Audit suggested that it would be cheaper to eat all babies at birth, do you think the Labor Party would be running whether that were a policy commitment? I am not going to give any more encouragement to the opposition on this cruel pursuit of individual groups in this community.

—Minister, if you think we are trying to frighten people, you are scaring them to death, I can assure you of that. Can you confirm that the Department of Social Security has advised you that applying an income and assets test to blind age pensioners from 1 July 1997 will save $228 million over four years?
—Mr President, they really are slow learners, aren't they? Haven't I given them assurance after assurance that I will not discuss what takes place within the confines of government?

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. I put to the minister: the government has already outlined a massive commitment to the environment and to the Natural Heritage Trust. What steps is the government now taking to develop national environmental standards and how will these guidelines give Australians the benefit of equivalent environment protection wherever they live?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the new Commonwealth government is taking a leading role in the development of national environmental standards. Anyone who has any contact with the industry at all will know that the industry, in so many of these issues of environmental standards, is in fact calling for national leadership.
—Doing away with the protection authority? What sort of leadership is that!

—This government has been able to do, Senator Bolkus, what yours was not able to do, and that is to hold the first meeting of the National Environment Protection Council over this last weekend. As I understand it, you had about three different attempts to hold a meeting but were unable to even achieve that small goal.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also pleased that at that meeting progress was made towards the development of four areas of national standard. The first was in relation to setting air quality goals across the country. The council agreed to the development of a draft measure pursuant to the NEPC legislation. That measure will aim to set standards for the six major pollutants in this instance in a cooperative way. Victoria is leading the project group and we are expecting that the draft measure will be presented to the next meeting of the NEPC to be held in November this year.

Secondly, the council agreed to the development of national guidelines to provide a system of tracking hazardous waste across state and territory boundaries. This is long overdue, because there is no national means at the moment to know where waste that tracks across state boundaries ends up. Again, there is a public interest to know that. It has all sorts of benefits in terms of applying pressure towards dealing with that waste in a responsible way. So that is the second area in which this council decided to work towards a national measure, which is pleasing.

Thirdly, the council agreed to work towards national guidelines for the assessment of contaminated sites. In this instance, ANZEC and the NHMRC have been currently working towards guidelines. They expect to report within six months and the matter will then be taken up by the NEPC. We hope that that will lead to the development of a national standard. In that instance, the project group is being headed by Western Australia.

Fourthly, the council agreed that the Commonwealth should continue to proceed with its plans to develop a national pollutant inventory. The former government spent some $4 million of taxpayers' money towards achieving that goal, but was unable to reach a conclusion. I am pleased that this council has decided that the Commonwealth should continue with that work. We have determined that it should proceed as a measure and come within the cooperative NEPC process. We expect to take to the next meeting in November a draft measure for consideration by the council. The first meeting of this body has now been held.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do away with the EPA, will you?

—It was first conceived, Senator Bolkus, in 1990 and established in 1992. Your government was not even able to hold a meeting let alone get anything constructive done. I am pleased that the new government has so quickly taken up the challenge, held the first meeting of this council and obtained cooperative support nationwide for achieving the goals that I have outlined. I trust that we will be able to come back in the not too distant future and see that the national standards are being put into place. That will certainly benefit the public Australia‐wide.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I read these things in the press too. If I took notice of everything that was in the press I would be concerned. Senator Collins has taken note of something in the press. I am not going to comment on anything that occurs at an ATSIC board; it is not my place to do so. I suggest that Senator Collins does not believe everything she reads in the press. I will not report on any ATSIC board meeting at all.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the events of the past month, do you, Minister, think it possible that you can repair your relationship with the ATSIC board and restore the confidence of Aboriginal people in your administration of this very vital portfolio?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, you told the Senate in answer to a question from Senator Bob Collins on 27 May that you did not think your appointment of a special auditor to ATSIC would force any delay in the provision of CEDP funds to Aboriginal communities. Are you aware that the Bunuba Aboriginal Corporation in Fitzroy Crossing has been officially informed that no funds for any ATSIC grants, including CDEP and essential services, will be released until at least 15 July because of the activities of your special auditor? Are you also aware that funds for more than 900 CDEP recipients in and around Fitzroy Crossing run out this Friday which means that they are now considering whether or not to sign up for unemployment benefits? Are you also aware that this corporation's sewerage system and water supply will stop without a continuation of its grants moneys and that the corporation is about to declare a state of emergency? What do you intend to do to immediately remedy this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —None of those things have occurred as a result of the appointment of the special auditor. You will recall that the special auditor has only just been appointed and has only just started action. They are the result of actions and a lot of misinterpretation of material which occurred as a result of the previous budget.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill in his capacity as both the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for the Environment. Can you confirm statements made by the Minister for Science and Technology on 60 Minutes last night that Woomera, in our home state of South Australia, is the national dump site for intermediate level radioactive waste? He also went on to say that we can take as much waste back from Dounreay as we need to. Is this correct? Does this mean all of the Dounreay radioactive waste material is going to Woomera? Have all the environmental assessments been completed for this?

—I did not see 60 Minutes last night. I doubt whether he would have described it as the national dump site. Certainly, the last Commonwealth government, as you know, determined that Woomera would become a temporary storage site for nuclear waste from a number of different sites in Australia—St Marys and Lucas Heights immediately come to mind. As I understand it, proper environmental assessments were made at that time. I think Australia is obliged to take back the waste from Scotland within 20 years. If I am correct, I think that is a bit inconsistent with what you said in your question. I think that is the case.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Woomera was only ever cleared for low level waste. The minister talked last night about intermediate level waste. Everything that comes back from Dounreay is going to be intermediate level waste. We have already sent 114 radioactive rods to Dounreay. We get back 85 times the volume in intermediate level waste. In other words, we will be getting back at least 15,000 litres of intermediate level waste. If we send all the rods to Dounreay, we will get back over 200,000 litres of intermediate level waste. If it is not going to Woomera, where is it going to go?

—The last government told us for years that it would establish a permanent repository at least for low level waste, but never got around to doing it. It established a temporary repository at Woomera. Most people thought that it would become the de facto permanent waste site. The issue about the definitions of `low' and `intermediate', as I understand—
—You have changed the definition.

—Senator Schacht, thank you for your intervention. At the request of the Democrats, the other day I saw the Greenpeace representatives who are particularly concerned with this matter. They argued that intermediate level waste is high level waste, and that low level waste is intermediate level waste. The definitional questions are really quite complex in this regard. I will go back to the science minister and seek clarification of what he said last night, and to see whether the new Commonwealth government has anything further to add. (Time expired)

—Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. Is the minister aware of the statement by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Cheryl Kernot, when she was interviewed on ABC radio's AM last Friday that the case for privatising Telstra ignores the benefits that flow to the community already from the $2 billion guaranteed income flow to the government? Would the minister agree that Senator Kernot's logic is fatally flawed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather sad when you are reduced to this line of argument. Every other excuse has been blown out of the water, so now we have this line that somehow there is this $2 billion of guaranteed income that might be put at risk. How can you possibly talk about a guaranteed stream of income for a corporation that is currently facing intense competition and will face even more competition from 1 July next year?

ANSWER.PARA: Just in case you are not aware of it, let me tell you that this very week Optus will announce a new local call charge rate. At the moment the local call business is worth about $5 billion out of about $12 billion total. If Optus actually manages to achieve, say, 15 to 20 per cent of market share, which is not unreasonable given what they have done with mobiles and long distance, 20 per cent of $5 billion would be $1 billion in revenue that Telstra could lose overnight—so much for this guaranteed $2 billion stream!

But it is much worse that, this logic, because in the financial year to July 1995, Telstra's profit after abnormals was about $1.7 billion. Nothing like that amount goes to the government. Obviously, any business that is making profits and has earnings after tax has to reinvest. Senator Kernot may have a 100 per cent dividend policy but we do not and nor did our predecessors.

Telstra finds it necessary at the moment to invest about $3.3 billion a year in upgrading the network, called the FMO. If you take that and put that to one side and ask yourself how much it actually gives to government each year, you will find that last year the dividend figure was about $790 million. Would it forego all of that for a one third privatisation? It would not; it would forego about a third of that, which is about $260 million.

Government debt at the moment is about $83 billion. I am sure Senator Kernot understands that our commitment, after giving $1 billion to the environment, is to use the remaining $7 billion from the sale—it may well be more—to repay government debt. At the moment the government is paying interest on that $7 billion of about eight per cent. In other words, $560 million of taxpayers' funds simply goes down the drain in debt reservice. Under our model—and under Senator Kernot's too if she followed the logic through—is that you would not have to pay that $560 million but you would lose $260 million. I would have thought that is a pretty good deal. You would be getting about twice your money.

The fact is that, far from the government foregoing $2 billion of revenue income, you would get all of that money up front. The net present value of that would be capitalised, so you would have all that money to invest. If you use it to repay debt, instead of wasting the money on debt service, you can use it on the things that you constantly argue should have more money spent on them. That is what it is all about. You would rather have the money going to repay interest and debt rather than having it to spend on welfare, housing, and all those other important issues that taxpayers' funds are raised for.

There is never enough, in your view, I know. You would like to have enormous amounts of money to spend. But just remember that at the present time it is not there. It is very scarce. You have a $8 billion deficit. What we are proposing is nothing more or less than a very sensible and modest approach, not squandering it, not splashing it up against the wall as this lot did. We are going to use it, not to pay for recurrent expenditure, but to retire debt. If you follow the logic through, you will find that is a very good deal for taxpayers. Shake your head as much as you like. All I can say is that you must have trotted out about 10 excuses to date; none of them has gone anywhere. This is the last desperate throw of the dice. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, last week Senator Bolkus asked me a question concerning the Australian Taxation Office's announcement that taxpayers would not be penalised for honest mistakes they made in preparing their tax returns using the Tax Pack , and he also asked several supplementary questions to that. I now have detailed answers to all the questions that Senator Bolkus put, and I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: Department of the Treasury
Australian Taxation Office
Response to Question Without Notice
Senator Bolkus asked the Assistant Treasurer a question without notice (Hansard , p1820), on 19 June 1996:

I refer the Minister to the Australian Taxation Office's announcement recently that taxpayers would not be penalised for honest mistakes that they make in preparing their tax returns using the Tax Pack. In view of this commitment by an arm of the Treasury department for which you have responsibility, Minister, can you explain why the Tax Office does, in fact, intend to charge interest in circumstances of honest taxpayer error in using the Tax Pack? Can you also explain what the rate of interest will be and what the anticipated level of revenue being raised by charging this interest will be? Can you also explain what action will be deemed to be an honest mistake and who will make that judgment?
Senator Short —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
Interest on Honest Mistakes

Where a taxpayer understates their taxable income and as such pays less tax than is required, the law provides for the imposition of both a penalty and interest component on the underpayment. The penalty is designed to address any culpability on the part of the taxpayer in underpaying tax. The Commissioner of Taxation has decided that where a taxpayer completes their own return and makes a genuine attempt to follow Tax Pack and its related publications, no culpability penalty should be imposed.

The interest component does not go directly to issues of culpability or honesty but rather reflects broadly the time value of money for late payment of tax payable to the Commonwealth. Reflecting its purpose, remission of interest is only applied in very limited circumstances.

Section 214A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 provides for interest payable on underpaid tax to be set at a rate that is based on the 13 week Treasury Note tender, plus 4 percentage points. The rate is generally reviewed every 6 months and notified in the Commonwealth Gazette. The interest rate applicable for the period 1 January 1996 to 30 June 1996 is 11.5% per annum. A rate for the period 1 July 1996 to 31 December 1996 is due to be gazetted before 30 June 1996.
Interest commences to run from the date when the tax became due and payable by the taxpayer under the original assessment and ends on the date on which the amended assessment is made.
It is estimated that any revenue raised from interest applied to underpayment of tax due to honest mistakes will be small.
Honest Mistake

In taking this decision on penalties, the Commissioner has effectively concluded that a taxpayer who makes a genuine attempt to follow Tax Pack and its related publications is exercising reasonable care under the law with the effect that no culpability penalty would apply in the case of a mistake.
Decisions on the application of penalties rest with taxation officers, generally in the context of an audit.

Guidance on reasonable care is included in Taxation Ruling 94/4 which as noted there, takes account of the circumstances of the particular taxpayer so that for example expectations of a pensioner would be different to those of an accountant.

Further, specific guidelines for audits of taxpayers using Tax Pack 1996 are to be developed. Audits are not expected to commence until the end of 1996. These guidelines will give further specific guidance on the application of penalties and will be consistent with the assurances given by the Commissioner on page 3 of the Tax Pack including that taxpayers using Tax Pack will not be expected to understand more than is contained in Tax Pack and its related publications. It is intended that members of professional bodies involved in the preparation of Tax Pack and the Special Adviser on Taxation in the Ombudsman's office will be consulted in the preparation of these guidelines.

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Sherry today, relating to the recommendations of the National Commission of Audit on superannuation and pensions.

In respect of the question that I put to Senator Short about why pensions were not included in the assessment of liabilities and superannuation was, the Commission of Audit in its report looks at the whole of government financial reporting section—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —What page?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just trying to find the page. It starts on page 361. If you look at the various tables of revenue and expenditure, the various dissections that occur there, we find in some detail—I think commendable detail in terms of the figures that are outlined—the list of `unfunded' superannuation liabilities.

PARA.BREAK: On the issue of unfunded superannuation liabilities for the public sector, it is important to note that the Labor government did initiate some important reforms in respect of public sector superannuation. The first change we made—and these are not necessarily in chron ological order—separated a number of financial institutions, such as Telstra, and ensured that they fully funded their own superannuation. There are about 100,000 people employed in those areas—or maybe a few more. So we did separate for the purposes of superannuation a considerable portion of the Public Service superannuation payroll and we ensured that their superannuation was fully funded. That is one change we made during our term in government.

ANSWER.PARA: The second change we made was to close down the old Commonwealth superannuation fund—that is detailed here in the appendix—and to introduce a new fund. We also introduced the superannuation guarantee—and I am not going to go into the details of that in the Senate chamber today.

A great deal has been made about the approximately $74 billion in unfunded superannuation liabilities for pension payments to public servants in either a lump sum or in a pension or annuity form. Part of the point in asking the question which Senator Short did not answer was: if we are to accept that superannuation is a liability in that way, why did not the Commission of Audit examine pensions in the same way? Just as superannuation is paid off the budget to former public servants and it is paid out of general budget revenue in the main—overwhelmingly, public sector superannuation is funded off the budget—why should we not treat pension payments, that again are funded totally off the budget from revenue, the same?

That was the point that I was hoping Senator Short would recognise. I was hoping he would inform us why the Commission of Audit did not treat pensions in the same way or at least make some reference to it.

I noticed that Senator Short had a speech I made last week drawn to his attention and he publicised it through the Senate and to the media. Thank you very much for that, Senator Short. I am very pleased for all the promotional efforts you have been making. I am not so sure you will be pleased with the promotion you have been getting as a consequence of question time as a result of the opposition's efforts.

BREAK.PARA: I want to make the point that the unfunded superannuation for public servants in this country has been accruing for over 50 years and it is not as a consequence of 13 years of Labor government. Let us be honest about it, Senator Short, it is a consequence of a succession of governments in this country. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Having briefly looked at the National Commission of Audit report, I notice that it does acknowledge, Senator Sherry, the need for further research. It goes so far as to recommend improvements in national savings. For example, on national savings the report states:

ANSWER.PARA: The government should undertake a comprehensive review of options for improving the contribution of household saving to national saving, including in the area of superannuation.

This review should entail a full review of tax and social security arrangements in terms of how they affect incentives to save. The review should also examine options for addressing the private saving offset problem and other options for stimulating private saving . . .
It goes on to say—and I will elaborate on each of these in a moment—that further research is needed. It states under the heading `Further research':

At this stage there is considerable uncertainty about the long term outlook for retirement incomes and, more specifically, the impact of compulsory superannuation. Much of this uncertainty cannot be avoided. However, it is probable that the community has yet to fully respond to the more recent superannuation reforms and therefore the data available upon which to project the impact of those reforms has been very limited. Given the importance of national saving trends to long term government economic and fiscal management, there appears to be scope and justification for continued work in retirement income data gathering and modelling to reduce this uncertainty.

The Commission notes the advances made to analysis of retirement income trends and policies by the RIM Task Force but considers this work incomplete, particularly in the analysis of private saving offsets to superannuation . . .
So in a sense, the report of the National Commission of Audit, which was given recently to the government, acknowledges the difficulties and acknowledges that there must be further work in this area.

BREAK.PARA: I think one of the problems, as you well know, Senator Sherry, is that nowadays we are really expecting too much of superannuation. We are having people wanting to use superannuation for all sorts of purposes, such as for deposits on houses, for education and for all these sorts of things.

What really is needed is an extension of the savings vehicles that are permitted within Australia. Perhaps our superannuation committee, Senator Sherry, may well look into other forms of savings that would complement superannuation. This would relieve a lot of pressure by requiring so many things which are not really commensurate with this concept of superannuation to be picked up by savings products other than superannuation.

As we all know, with superannuation you must start contributing early and saving over that very long period of about 40 years to have any hope of getting the income needed to provide for the normal requirements in retirement—certainly to provide above the current level of the age pension. This is a prime requirement.

Perhaps we should move away from the concept of unfunded government superannuation liabilities. The sooner governments start funding liabilities, putting moneys aside and building up reserves, the sounder the finances of the Australian nation will be. The concept of unfunded superannuation contributions has been a problem for many years. Without funding, it makes nonsense of the concept of true accrual accounting.

For every entity, whether it be a government entity, a public organisation or private enterprise, the entity should allocate all the expenses attributable to that period. Those expenses include a portion of long service leave and superannuation as they build up during the period under review. Provision should be made for each of these components of cost. The best way to make these provision is to set the money aside in some form of trust fund or vehicle where it can be invested and earning interest.

Recent superannuation performance in this country has been remarkably good. I take my hat off to all those hundreds of thousands of superannuation trustees who have made such a significant contribution to the prudential safeguarding of superannuation in this country. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.
We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:
Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are opposed to any moves to cut funding to universities. We believe that funding cuts to universities can only be to the detriment of an educated and democratic society. We believe that a broadly accessible and liberating higher education system is fundamental to efforts at creating a more just and equitable society.
In particular we are opposed to any attempts to:

PARA.TAB: introduce up front fees for any students, including any attempt to allow universities to charge up front fees to students enrolled in excess of Commonwealth funded quotas;
increase the level of debt incurred by students through the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS);
lower the level at which HECS debts must be repaid through the taxation system;
replace the grant based component of the AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY scheme with a loans scheme;
expand the loans component of AUSTUDY/ABSTUDY;
cut funding on a per student basis, in particular operating grants; and
cut the number of Commonwealth funded places already in the system or promised during the previous Parliament.

PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the petitioners here undersigned oppose the cuts made to programs associated with the provision of labour market assistance to the unemployed.
We view the decision to make these cuts as ill advised and in contravention of the Government's pre‐election commitments to maintain services to the unemployed.
We call on all members of Parliament, regardless of political party to do everything possible and ensure that:
1. The Government maintain the real level of labour market program funding at levels equal to or greater than that provided for under the previous Government's Working Nation Initiatives.

2. The Government recognises the value of the current Skillshare program as a community provider of services to the unemployed and make provision for the continued existence of, and extension to, this highly successful program.

3. The Government immediately declares a moratorium on any cuts to funding for community based program providers of services to the unemployed and enter into discussions with peak industry advocates, representatives of the unemployed and representatives of employees employed in these services about the most effective ways to deliver these services. That no changes be made to the delivery of these services until these discussions occur.

4. The Government does everything possible to ensure that the experienced and trained employees currently engaged in the provision of community based labour market assistance programs be maintained in these services in order to ensure that unemployed people get the greatest possible opportunity to be successful in gaining meaningful employment.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislation program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
(1) The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

(2) The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

(3) The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
(4) Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
(5) The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
(6) The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
(7) The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

(8) The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with overaward gender based pay equity issues.
(9) A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
(10) Workers under State industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a comment concerning the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. This bill that has come about, as I understand it, because of a recent decision in Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission v. the Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Because of a conflict between section 256 of the Migration Act and paragraph 26B of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act, the government's hands are tied in relation to dealing with a type other than was intended when dealing with illegal entries.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's position is that we have a responsibility to enforce the immigration laws pursuant to the Migration Act. As I said, the interpretation of this demonstrates an unintended consequence. Therefore, the government has an obligation to remove as quickly as possible that unintended consequence, thus permitting the continued timely removal of current unauthorised arrivals.

The decision in that case was only very recently handed down, and the government has expeditiously sought the passage of an amending bill to overcome the problem. That bill has been introduced into the Senate, and the Senate wishes the bill to be examined by a Senate committee through our reference of bills to committee process.

Whilst we do not object to that process, as this is the last sitting week and as this unintended consequence is likely to apply to a large number of new cases before the parliament sits again, we would hope that the Senate committee could consider this matter during the course of this week. I would suggest to the committee chairman that Wednesday night might be a good night to listen to the human rights arguments and to put down the government's concerns, with the objective being that the committee would report before the end of the week and the Senate would still have time to consider the bill during this last week of sittings.

Although the committee has as its reference day the first day of the next sitting, I understand that has always been interpreted in the past as being on or before that day. In this instance, the government is anxious that it be interpreted as being before that day, provided the committee can give the matter proper consideration this week and the chamber can still deal with it this week.

These very urgent matters do arise from time to time. Although it may not allow the Senate the length of deliberation that it requires in normal circumstances, the Senate has nevertheless usually accepted that, in exceptional circumstances, the processes should fit the time available. We will ensure that those witnesses who should be heard do get the opportunity to be heard during this week.
