SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The content of this report should concern all senators. Unfortunately, we do not know the outcome of the further indications from the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) with respect to the Senate budget but this report, specifically the comments on the budget allocation to the operations of the Senate, is deeply disturbing.

The report mentions under the heading `Budget 1996-97' on page 3 that the two per cent efficiency dividends—one per cent in 1995-96 and another one per cent in 1996‐97—have been absorbed over the past five years. On top of that, there was an additional two per cent reduction in the 1995-96 budget.

PARA.BREAK: The President has been asked by the finance minister to absorb in 1996‐97 a further two per cent reduction in running costs. That amounts to a $623,000 reduction in the operational budget of the Senate. On top of that, the President and Speaker have been asked to find a further $10 million in savings, of which the Senate's component is approxi mately $500,000, in a year. That brings the total reductions in Senate funding in one year to $1,123,000—approximately a seven per cent to eight per cent reduction.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a massive reduction in Senate appropriations. If we look through the budget that is proposed for the operations of the Senate, we find many areas of operation of the Senate will be affected. To name just a few, the staff development budget is to be reduced by 50 per cent; various staffing arrangements of parliament, including parliamentary committees, are to be significantly affected; and the installation of computers for senators and their staff is to be affected. They are just a few areas which are to be affected by reductions.

The report goes on and makes it very clear that the reductions, particularly for the committee structure of the Senate, will without doubt affect the operations of the committee system—the legislative, the general purpose and the select committee structure. It also refers to a breaking of an agreement with the President by the finance minister in respect of how Senate committees are funded. Where has this come from? Where has the approach of the finance minister, Mr Fahey, come from? It has come from the Expenditure Review Committee.

Page 5 of the report makes it very clear that the committee was informed by the Department of Finance on 14 June that the proposals on expenditure had been rejected by the Expenditure Review Committee. Some $866,000 has been severely reduced as a consequence of the approach of the Expenditure Review Committee. Who is on the Expenditure Review Committee? I will not run through the membership of it, but it is the executive government. What we have here is the executive cutting back the funding of the Senate, particularly the Senate committees—the legislative, general purpose and select committees.

It is true that when we were in government we certainly had complaints about the number of select committees running rampant around the country. I think at one stage we had six or seven operating at once. There were arguments about funding, but we never attempted to throttle or gut the committee system of the Senate by breaking a pre-existing agreement and by rolling back the budget of the Senate by over $1 million. This will have very severe consequences for the operation of this place, particularly for our committee system.

The operation of the Senate is going to be substantially affected. The government should not complain if legislation takes longer to move through the committee system than would normally be expected. How can the government scream, shout and complain about obstruction—and there is no obstruction in our approach to the government's program—when the committees are not funded adequately? How can the committees do their job when there is not sufficient money to examine the government's legislation?

What we have here is an example of the government creating a bottleneck by slashing the funding of the committee structure of the Senate. Do not complain if committees take longer to consider the government's legislative program than would otherwise normally be expected when we have a cutback of more than $1 million in the operations of the Senate—particularly as it applies in a range of areas to the committee system and when we have the breaking of an agreement by the finance minister and his department on instructions from the ERC.

Clearly the Expenditure Review Committee is attempting to throttle and restrict the work of the Senate and particularly its committees. It is creating a problem that it will have to address. It certainly cannot complain if legislation takes longer to move through the committee system than is the norm as a direct result of the cutbacks in select committee and general staff funding that are outlined in what is quite a horrific budget for this Senate; it is a horrific budget to have to face up to. I was pleased to see at the two meetings of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, which I attended, that all senators present, including government senators, expressed their extreme concern with what is proposed in the budget for this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak today on the appropriations and staffing report. The inter esting thing today is not so much just the implications for the Senate but the fact that this is what has been cut by the Senate in the knowledge that the Senate does have the ability to review such issues. I gather it is going to be worse than the House of Representatives and the joint committees, largely because the Senate does not have the ability to look at what is being done.

SPEECH.PARA: If anybody is assuming that we are being asked to make `efficiency cuts', they should ask, `What is the definition of efficiency?' My definition of efficiency is that you are able to do the job you are required to do by using fewer resources. Then you have to ask, `Has the Senate got less work?' No. In fact as time goes on the Senate is being asked to deal with more and more pieces of legislation which often have great complexities. If you are dealing with issues of government business enterprises, the sale thereof and so on, you are dealing with extremely intricate issues that involve a great deal of important and careful consideration.

Do committees need less to operate than what they used to before? What can you cut out? There seems to be $200,000 that is being cut in administrative savings. What do you do? Do you go to fewer places for hearings? Do you offer fewer people airfares or cost contributions to attend hearings?

A particular favourite one of mine is that we should be moving towards the ability to use more multimedia in the way we have hearings. Unfortunately, the way things work at the moment the committees are being asked to shoulder the cost of any telecommunications link‐up, though these kinds of issues have not been dealt with in any Telstra bill. But committees are being asked to shoulder those burdens.

Other departments look after senators airfares and so on. But, if a committee were to hear evidence or be attended by a committee member or a participating member by videoconference or teleconference, the committee ends up shouldering that responsibility and the cost. They shouldn't have to, because they do not necessarily have to pay the airfares of senators. It should be balanced off between what the taxpayer has to pay. But at the moment what is standing in the way of enabling greater participation, greater access and greater equity is the fact that committees are being asked to pay.

I can see that that will probably be out of the question. You will have to say, `What functions of this committee are we going to drop off?' What happens when it comes to the crunch and the committee says, `We have run out of money. We have done the things we are supposed to do in the normal way, but there is no more money so we have to stop this inquiry.' What sort of democracy is this? What right, under the constitution, does a new government have to say, `You have been elected as senators. You have this much work to do. This is what the community expects you to do, but we are not going to let you do it. We are going to slow down the process. Each committee will handle fewer inquiries—that is the inevitable aspect of providing fewer resources—and then we are going to blame you if the work is not completed on time.' Is that the implication of this report?

This report talks about things like catering at estimates hearings being terminated. When we are working until 11.30 at night there will be no cup of tea, there will be nothing, for those people who may not be able to leave the estimates committee hearing because they do not know at what point they can ask their series of questions. Basically, you are saying to the people in the small parties, who cannot pick and choose the representatives they want at those estimates committees, that they either miss out on a part of the estimates if they need a cup of tea or biscuit to survive until 11.30 at night or they do without. These are silly things, but they relate to the good running of this place.

The report talks about printing costs of $30,000. I assume you are saying that you can cover that through privatisation. What control and accountability does the Senate have if that system does not work. Some $115,000, half of the $230,000 allocation, is going to be taken off staff development. When we need people to keep up on the issues and when we need to understand new technology that means you are not going to provide them. Who are you going to blame when those situations become obvious? We do not need staff development any more; is that what people are suggesting? Will we then blame the individuals if problems result from less staff development.

There are going to be cuts to the Australian Protective Service. That must mean that we do not need them any more and there are no security problems in Australia and things must be getting better. The government's definition of efficiency is that things are getting better therefore we do not need the Australian Protective Service.

You obviously do not understand the issues surrounding computers and computer technology if you expect us to deal with the fast changes in technology using systems that are out of date and which you think are acceptable. The newspaper supply is going to be cut by one-third. You will say to us, `We will not make available to you one of your daily newspapers.' We will have to choose which of our papers we can do without. This is outrageous.

The report talks about security attendants. We will have to send a message to the general public saying, `Please make sure that any security threats occur during the daytime.' It is like saying to customs, `Please make sure that anybody wanting to smuggle anything into Australia, such as drugs, contraband, et cetera, does it during the daytime.' That is like what you are saying in relation to security. If there are going to be security threats, they have to make them when you have people on security.

It is not that this is the greatest outrage I am seeing at the moment. This is the thinnest bit of what we are seeing throughout the community. The outrage is that it has nothing whatsoever to do with efficiency. It has nothing whatsoever to do with anything except an ideological push to cut expenditure on the assumption that cutting is good. I think you are actually taking some things away from the people who have voted for us. They have voted for us to do the job we were elected to do. If the Senate needs another select committee because of the work we are required to do then there is no choice I believe except for that to be funded. It is not the government's place to stop the democratic process of review which the Senate is charged with.

Basically, I think this is an atrocious report. The real problem is that this is happening not just to us but right across the system. Just about everybody who is presented with these kinds of figures—that is, if they are presented and quite frankly they usually are not—is finding that they are having to do more with less. That is not efficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should first of all ponder where all the Senate chauvinists have gone today when this report has come up. I do not think it is possible for the Senate to avoid participating in the cost cutting exercise that the current government is undertaking. It would be most unfair for the Senate to be exempted when every other department in government is required to contribute to a savings program. However, there are some very strange aspects to the way this has been approached. I do not allege a conspiracy by the government to try to stitch up the Senate. This has been driven from elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three lots of cuts coming into the Senate's budget in the next financial year. The first is the $10 million cut to parliamentary departments, which, in a budget of $120 million, is quite severe—almost of ABC proportions one suspects. It is in the order of a seven or eight per cent cut off the top. That is going to have quite a lot of ramifications around this building.

A lot of the cuts will relate to equipment replacement and maintenance. This means that we will build problems over the long term. Equipment, such as the cameras filming everyone in here, the sound system and the airconditioning system, will break down. They will gradually run down given the effects of those cuts. It is a requirement on the Senate to at least contribute half a million dollars of its usual budget of around $23 million or $24 million to that process. It is an election promise that you can say the government is keeping.

PARA.BREAK: The second cut is a cut of two per cent to running costs. This affects the Department of the Senate as severely as any other depart ment because all the expenditure for the Department of the Senate, bar a couple of minor items, are running costs. If you were to apply a two per cent cut to a lot of other departments, you might affect only 30, 40 or 50 per cent of their total budgets. Basically, this two per cent cut is to 100 per cent of the expenditure of the Department of the Senate. Furthermore, it comes on top of a one per cent efficiency dividend operating since 1991, a special levy in the last budget, and other cuts that the Department of the Senate has had to incorporate into its budget process over the last five years.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the details of where the proposed cuts will hit, we find they will affect the efficiency of this place. Senator Margetts mentioned information, such as the amount of newspapers. I am not sure whether she mentioned the clipping service, which is up for axing. There is a range of things that will affect the way in which senators carry out their duties.

I should add that these measures are not set in concrete. Here I pay tribute to the staff of the Senate because they had to get a proposal together. Whereas we can criticise some aspects of the proposed cuts and prefer others, it has been their onerous duty to put this proposal together. But I think it is inevitable that the Senate will put forward $500,000 as part of the $10 million cut. I also think it is inevitable that the two per cent cut to running costs will go ahead. How could you exempt the Senate from cuts that apply to every other department? You could not.

This matter really comes down to a question of funding the committee system, a matter which has been subject to debate in this chamber on many occasions with many accusations being made. The real story is that agreements were forged last year after a long series of disagreements between the then Minister for Finance and the Senate department. Essentially, that agreement allocated two half‐million dollar blocks to the committee system. This year those agreements were abrogated; an official of the Department of Finance ripped them up. There has been no acknowledgment to us so far that the present Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey, endorsed that action; they were just ripped up.

If anyone is looking for the driving force behind this action, they need look no further than the Department of Finance. The present minister, Mr Fahey, is going along with the department but the driving force is that malignant government department, the Department of Finance. Its behaviour in the last two or three months is something that people on the other side of this chamber should start noting.

Every crackpot scheme that the Department of Finance trailed before the then Labor government over the last 13 years, and which we knocked back, is now being trailed before the new ministry in the hope that their lack of experience or naivety will mean a lack of critical approach. I am sure that a lot of those schemes will be knocked back again but the Department of Finance, this driving force, wants to cut parliamentary departments as much as it can. And Minister Fahey is responsible to this parliament in as much as he represents that department and examines those schemes.

The effect of the agreement with the Minister for Finance last year is that the standing committees will not be properly staffed. Consequently, they will not be able to examine legislation properly, which will slow down the overall process. Furthermore, they will cut the critical faculties necessary for the various references they have been given, references which would be of assistance not only to this parliament but to government as a whole.

It has to be said that a majority of committee reports come down in a non‐partisan way and every now and then they come up with some pretty good ideas. It is equally true that they come up with a lot of ratbag ideas which are knocked back in the winnowing‐out process of government. But all that will go down the drain if we allow the Department of Finance to renege on its previous arrangement.

It is also true that we have a difficulty with select committees because we do not know how many of the existing ones will remain in the next financial year and how many new ones might be established. Currently we have four select committees, two of which existed in the previous parliament. The assumption is that if there is only enough money for two of these committees, they will be the two.

The Senate has not made that decision yet. It has not decided whether the superannuation committee and the other—which, I think, is a video committee—will have precedence over the uranium committee and the Victorian casino committee. However, we might be forced to make that decision if the Minister for Finance does not properly fund the Senate for these particular programs.

As I pointed out the other day in a question to Senator Short, it is quite convenient that the two committees currently in the gun are the two which this government least wants to proceed with. I do not allege a conspiracy. I do not allege that the Minister for Finance on behalf of the coalition has said, `I do not like a couple of these inquiries, so we'll starve the Senate of funds.' There is no such allegation to be made.

However, I do ponder this: there seems to be a lack of incentive on the part of the government to resolve this matter and to help out these two select committees. You would not be behaving humanly on the other side if that were not in the back of your minds somewhere. But if that be the case, I am sure the Senate will take action to ensure that the resources are found for those two committees at the expense of some government project or some other thing.

I am not asking the Department of Finance and the Minister for Finance to give special treatment to the Senate. The Senate must be treated in the same way as every other government department. It cannot be exempt—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your government was going to cut $10 million off it, too.

—Thank you for that, Senator Calvert. You would have noticed that I said that we cannot complain about the $10 million cut. We cannot even complain about, although I do not agree with it, the two per cent cut to running costs. I am sure that you would be gracious enough to acknow ledge that the Senate is all running costs so the impact of a two per cent cut is very severe.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure you do not want your newspaper allocation cut. I am sure you do not want the clippings service cut. I am sure you do not want the Parliamentary Education Office cut in half. I am sure that you want proper and secure conditions around this building, not for yourself—you are a brave individual—but so that your staff members can work in a secure environment. You want all those things, Senator Calvert, but they cannot be done on the current funding.

Further, you would not want your government to have the reputation that it cannot keep its word, even though the commitment came from the previous government. This agreement was between the Department of the Senate and the Department of Finance. It was ripped up without even consultation with the President. There was just a letter to say that the agreement no longer existed.

The argument comes down to this: this is new policy; if you want that extra $1 million, you will have to find offsetting savings. On top of a one per cent efficiency dividend and a special two per cent cut to running costs, in order to find that $1 million you will need to put another eight or nine per cent cut on running costs. No‐one would argue that you should be suffering so with running costs, with cuts of 12 to 14 per cent over a couple of years. That would be an absolute joke.

This report should be supported by the Senate in a bipartisan way, not just in a Senate chauvinistic way. For the sake of maintaining the basic running of this particular chamber, the Department of Finance and the Minister for Finance should be kept to their words and committee funding should go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with a lot of what Senator Ray says, but there is some of what he said that I do not agree with. One proposition is that the Department of the Senate should be treated the same as every other department. I do not think that is right.
—I was always the democrat; you were always the elitist.
—You say you are a democrat, Senator Ray.
—A left‐handed one.

—The very essence of democracy is that parliament should have the overall say in how the country is governed. If we are going to have a federal parliament, surely the most central function it has is to act like a parliament. If you look at the constitution, of the first 80 sections 60 are devoted to the parliament, 10 to the executive and 10 to the judiciary. I see Kim Rubenstein up the gallery. She is a very eminent academic from the University of Melbourne—a most august body with a most august law school. I do not know what she would be thinking of the way we are dealing with the parliament here today.

BREAK.PARA: Certainly, I am not saying that there should not be cuts to the Department of the Senate, but those cuts should be determined by the Senate itself. There is concern about the way democracy is going and that concern has been expressed by very eminent people. One, for example, is the present Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Gerard Brennan, who, in the Blackburn lecture in August 1990, had this to say:

Apart from legislative debates, Parliament's continuing contribution to democracy is its holding of the Executive to public accountability. Moreover, it scrutinises proposed appropriations and delegations of power and reviews subordinate legislation . . . But the capacity of parliament to place a check on executive action is limited by the press of business and the day‐to‐day exigencies of politics.

I think all of us in this chamber over the years have given speeches about the necessity of democracy and the necessity of parliament. Deep down, I think all of us are parliamentary people. There is the press of the fact that we are members of parties. In respect of two of those parties, they take it in turns, as it were, to form the government of this country. Once you form the government of the country, there is great pressure to fall in with the proper demands of the executive. But there are certain times when the demands made by the executive are not proper—they go beyond the reality as set out by the tests of a democracy and as set out by the constitution. This is one such case. There is a distinction to be drawn between the Department of the Senate and other departments, that is, that this department goes to serving us who, after all, are the only people directly elected by the constituents in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 31 of 1995-96: Performance audit—Environmental management of Commonwealth land—site contamination and pollution prevention .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Senator MICHAEL BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is a very important report because it demonstrates an extraordinary lack in management, certainly by previous governments, of this vital problem of environmental management of Commonwealth land, particularly site contamination and pollution prevention. The intriguing thing that emerges from this is that there is no central land managing authority in the Commonwealth. Land management responsibility is vested in a whole range of Commonwealth entities, particularly the Depart ment of Defence, which has many unexploded ordnance problems around, but also the Department of Administrative Services, each individual government business enterprise and some particular statutory authorities. There are national parks and the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, particularly dealing with Australia's external territories.

The lack of such a central body in charge of this problem means that a range of problems, from disastrous to moderate, have emerged in some of these potential arrangements for disposal. There is a very large amount of money involved here. For example, we keep on hearing about the previous government selling off the farm, but one of the interesting things about the previous government was that, in the three years from December 1992 to December 1995, returns to the budget from flogging 792 federal government properties exceeded $440 million. From the audit report I am not quite certain whether that includes returns to GBEs which did not in fact involve a specific benefit to the budget, but there is no doubt that some of these GBEs did raise quite an amount of money.

It is also noted in the audit report that most of the GBEs did not appear to have any particular guidelines about how they should perform when disposing of contaminated land. The Audit Office found in its report that:

. . . departmental oversight of GBEs' performance in terms of managing environmental risks is patchy and inconsistent. For example, while Telstra has clear guidelines as to the Government's expectations on environmental performance, other entities such as Australia Post and Australian National do not. Australian National in particular has major contamination problems with some of its sites. The ANAO found that these departments could become more proactive in oversighting environmental issues (including site contamination and pollution issues) of the GBEs within their portfolios. The benefits of a more proactive position relate to the achievement of Government environmental policy and financial objectives for GBEs.

One of the problems is that, even with those GBEs that do have clear guidelines as to government expectations on environmental performance, they do not necessarily live up to them. In Sydney I have heard of examples where Telstra has disposed of local properties which in fact have had enormous contamination problems resulting in at least one incident I know of when the sale had to be cancelled.

I suppose there is a balance. The question is to what extent do you constrain these organisations very severely without in fact severely damaging their capacity to raise appropriate amounts of money. The Audit Office, being involved with money, found that:

. . . strategic oversight mechanisms were needed to ensure that the real value of the Commonwealth's assets is maintained; current administrative arrangements do not encourage entities to be fully accountable for their environmental performance.

I think that is a very significant point that the Auditor‐General has made. I must say that I hope the new government responds to that need in a way that the previous government, over 13 years, did not adequately do. In this context, I read on from the report:

In relation to the estate which AEM managed directly, the ANAO found that AEM was seeking to meet State legislative requirements in relation to known site contamination problems. However, in the absence of a systematic environmental risk assessment, the ANAO considers that AEM was not in a position to assess the full extent of contamination and potential pollution risks of its estate.

I know this is a problem because there are state laws and these are federal bodies, but it really looks as though something much more positive should be done than has been done over the last 13 years. The audit report says:

AEM was not as advanced in assessing its environmental risks as some other agencies audited. However, AEM indicated that it intended to commence a contamination risk assessment of its estate during 1996‐97.
This seems to me to be a very delayed reaction to the sorts of problems we have known have existed for quite some time. The report continues:

The ANAO also found that property managers at seven of AEM's regional offices had not received any recent training on environmental issues and site contamination information was not collected on a regular basis to assist land management decisions.
Clearly this is a serious problem.

Unexploded ordnance is another question which I know Senator MacGibbon has some views about. The Audit Office reports that resources allocated by Defence to address unexploded ordnance contamination on non‐Commonwealth land have been inadequate to achieve the government's policy objectives within a reasonable time frame. This is not a happy report for the previous government. It clearly exposes its inadequacies in this area.
I conclude by reading this final extract from the Audit Office report:

Despite being under consideration since 1993 by the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (EPA), there is no specific Commonwealth legislation or formal policy to guide Commonwealth land management entities in tackling environmental matters such as pollution prevention and site contamination. As a consequence, environmental management is afforded a low priority and is often an afterthought dealt with when sites are scheduled for sale. The ANAO notes that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, administered by the EPA, has rarely been applied for site assessment and remediation activities.
As I said, this is a very important report. It certainly provides this government with a challenge to clear up the mess left by the previous government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to make some brief statements about the Environmental Management of Commonwealth Land—Site Contamination and Pollution Prevention report of the Australian National Audit Office. Should anyone want a horror story, all they have to do is flick over to the pictures in the report showing how quite serious waste has been treated on Commonwealth sites. On page 23 there is a picture which is of particular concern to me. We can see used drums stored in the open on an air force base. Quite clearly visible on the side of one of the drums is `PCB'. There are drums on their sides, some of which are rusting, used for the storage of PCBs. It would not be acceptable anywhere. Under normal circumstances somebody, or a number of people, would be prosecuted. This is simply not good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Audit Office conducts reviews, they usually have to base their audit on required standards or guidelines. As mentioned, there is no specific Commonwealth legislation or formal policy to guide Commonwealth land management entities. The necessity for such a policy becomes even more important when we consider the level of privatisation and development over the last few years of government business enterprises. Those business enterprises are often asked to pull a profit when playing a government role in buying and selling land. However, often they have not been involved with such things before—for example, the Department of Defence. Then there are longstanding problems with land if there is contamination or, in the case of defence, unexploded ordnances. But without any clear guidelines, lots of these decisions are made when spurred by information that the community is able to obtain or when concerns are expressed.

The Senate would clearly recall my concerns about the land at St Marys in western Sydney where you have the whole kit and caboodle—a water problem, nitrification, endangered flora and fauna species and contamination caused by unexploded ordnances. Basically, when a government enterprise is operating on a commercial basis and at the same time has a long‐running exemption from state and federal laws, whatever happens tends to be selective. That is not good enough, and it is certainly not a good enough standard for the Commonwealth to set.

Some of the recommendations are not very clear—for example, the development of a proposal for consideration by ministers to clarify the Commonwealth's policy position on contaminated sites. In regard to the recommendation that there be a commitment from land management entities to administer pollution prevention, detection and remediation, it is no good having rules if nobody is going to enforce them.

PARA.BREAK: Another recommendation is that there be a more proactive approach to oversighting the environmental performance of government business enterprises where there may be high financial or environmental risks. If you want to make money from a land sale, you do not then sweep things under the carpet. For example, senators may remember the questions I asked about why the St Marys site was not available for the western Sydney biodiversity survey. Answer: there is no reason except the fact that Australian Defence Indus tries would not allow the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service to conduct the survey. No reason was given. There were indications of endangered flora and fauna species on the site that needed to be looked at more carefully and the western Sydney biodiversity survey wanted to look at what environmental resources existed in western Sydney. But ADI said, `No, you can't look at this area.'

SPEECH.PARA: I go back to the list of recommendations. The list includes: a commitment from Commonwealth land management entities to have full regard to state and territory environmental regulations—yes, and it is long overdue; more strategic and timely identification of the impact of environmental issues on the Commonwealth disposal program; consideration of introducing independent auditing of environmental performance to protect the value of Commonwealth land assets; and a demonstrable commitment to protecting the environment.

People around Australia will be stunned to think that the Commonwealth, whose main environmental efforts tend to be to exhort other people to do better, is not doing a good job with its own properties; is using its exemptions from state and federal laws to make commercial decisions; and is using exemptions under commercial in confidence provisions for its government business enterprises not to be accountable to the parliamentary process. People will know how that has been the case, based on the questions that I have asked on a number of occasions.

It is simply not good enough. I am very keen to see the response to this by government departments. But it really is not up to government departments: it is up to the government and the parliamentary process to institute these changes and to make sure that they are properly enforced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —Report No. 31 of 1995‐96 from the Australian National Audit office, Environmental management of Commonwealth land , is a very interesting one which a couple of previous speakers have addressed. It raises some very real questions about the state of land in Australia which certainly need to be addressed. They certainly need to be cleaned up because, at the end of the day, environmental matters are simply good housekeeping. None of us want to live in a garbage heap.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to maintain a degree of balance about this report. There are some pretty nasty pictures there. But looking at more industrialised countries like the United States and Europe, their problems, purely as a consequence of higher density populations, are far worse than any we face. Some of those, I would think, are quite irremedial, whereas ours, I believe, are all remedial if we have the will, which I hope we do.

The stories coming out of pollution behind the Iron Curtain countries in Eastern Europe, particularly in some of their defence facilities, are really quite horrendous and far beyond any scale that exists in Australia. Looking at some of the problems of the former Soviet empire, for example, the Kola Peninsula, with their nuclear weapons, particularly their nuclear submarines, the mind boggles that those can ever be cleaned up. But I do think the problem is manageable in Australia if we turn our minds to it and I believe it is a matter of urgency that we should do so.

The particular part of the report I wish to refer to is the section on unexploded ordnance because my own state of Queensland is by far and away the worst affected state in Australia. On page 40 of this report there is a table listing the unexploded ordnance sites in Australia. Queensland is listed with 403 sites that have been identified. That may not be the maximum figure; it may well be higher than that. New South Wales is next with 169 and a total of just over 1,000 sites are identified around Australia. So Queensland, very roughly, has about half the sites that have been recorded so far. That is not surprising because Queensland was the major training ground, particularly for land forces, through the Second World War when most of this pollution occurred. It is very easy today for someone who was not alive at that time to look back and think there was a great degree of negligence about at that time.

But it must be remembered that at that time the population of Australia was about seven million. We were facing a desperate attack on our own homeland by Japan and there was not the culture of concern for the environment 50 or 60 years ago that exists today. There was a great urgency to train and prepare. There were relatively huge numbers: probably five divisions of the Australian military forces training in Queensland and over a quarter of a million Americans passed through Queensland in that period from 1942 to 1945.

So there was a great deal of live ammunition used in training. The general ethos was that if there was no‐one around to be harmed by the blast, if it was an open part of the countryside with no habitation and there was a camp nearby, it was used as a training range. The consequence is that records are poor or non‐existent in some cases. Lest you think that was purely a matter of the Second World War, let me say that I can remember as a small boy going to a brigade training exercise behind the Sunshine Coast in Queensland. The air force was bombing onto the sand dunes and the army was firing from Noosaville with 25‐pounders into an impact area on the beach somewhere behind Peregian. That had been a training area from the Second World War through to certainly the early part of the 1950s and, I suspect, into the middle of the 1950s.

In all those cases there was not any monitoring of the fall of shot as there is today when firing artillery to make sure all the blinds are detected, sought out afterwards and detonated. The consequence is that there are these areas where old munitions exist. Old munitions are extremely dangerous. The explosive often becomes unstable with age and the munitions are often not recognisable as such—because of the corrosion and the exposure to the elements—by children seeking things to play with. In real estate developments, excavators and bulldozers could easily disturb something. So we do have a real problem. The liability of the Commonwealth is a bit obscure as paragraph 3.50 on page 40 of the report states:
Since the Policy—
that is, the policy on land clearance—

was finalised, the Department has not paid compensation to any land owners as a result of UXO contamination of land where the Commonwealth no longer possesses, or never possessed a legal interest. However, as noted in legal advice obtained by the ANAO, the Commonwealth's legal liability depends on the circumstances of each particular case. At the end of World War II, compensation was paid to some land owners at the time for damage to property caused during the occupation. In other cases no record of compensation can be found at all.

The problem is made complex again by the existence of state legislation. It is a plausible argument in some cases that the problem is more a state matter than a Commonwealth matter. The problem is now rearing itself in Queensland, and has for the last several years, as urban development takes place in areas that were formerly remote. There are great arguments running as to who should pick up the tab for cleaning up those sites.

The state government in Queensland has been particularly reluctant to buy into it. The Commonwealth, if it never owned the land or had sold the land and had paid compensation to the previous owners, quite rightly said, `We paid compensation for it and the owners bought this land at a discounted price and with full knowledge that the land was contaminated.' The fact that that might have been 20 or 30 years ago and the purchaser today may be three or four down the chain, is not aware or does not recognise the history, is another matter again as far as the Commonwealth's liability is concerned.

I do not have time today to go into the legal arguments. All I will say is that we have been lucky to have had so few deaths from unexploded ordnance upon these sites. I do not think the sites are heavily infested with unexploded ordnance but there is certainly some ordnance there—and it has to be cleaned up. The role of the Commonwealth, as I see it, is to move in in a coordinating role, assign responsibilities to various people and put a scheme in place so that these areas are cleaned up because all these areas are going to be used by Australian citizens for development in some way in the foreseeable future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to briefly put on record, as a member of the public works committee and a former deputy chair of that committee, the fact that I am pleased to see that the Auditor‐General has highlighted the problems that we identified not so long ago. He has also highlighted the fact that there seems to be no policy position by successive governments on cleaning up contaminated sites. As we found when we were inspecting a particular case at Albion in Melbourne, there seemed to be very little knowledge of how to clean up these sites.

SPEECH.PARA: On our inspection we were told that it was going to cost something like $400,000. In the next report the sum was creeping up towards a million dollars and then, with very little prompting, they said it could go as high as $15 million. This kept rolling on until they suggested something like $30 million. In this report it says $50 million but it looked as though it could have gone to $100 million if we had not said, `Hang on a minute.' It was open ended. There was no policy or knowledge. They had a steam cleaning arrangement on site that was supposed to be cleaning up the soil where there were remnants of TNT. We were concerned as a committee—not that we did not believe the advice we had been given—about the escalation in costs. Through our committee—and it shows the advantages of the committee system—we employed a private consultant who made the point of asking, `How far do you go with some of these suspected contaminants in the soil?'

We looked at a couple of sites where a lot of work had been done in this area of so-called toxins. This consultant said, `How far can you go in these things? You could go into the backyard of someone who has been growing brussels sprouts and cabbages and find just as much toxin in the ground from them as you would from this contaminant. It is a question of degree.' Given the escalating costs and what was developing, we recommended that things be put on hold until we were satisfied that there was better knowledge of what was going on and some more direction from the powers that be.

On the other hand, at another site that we all know about—Maralinga—we were lucky to see the new in situ vitrification process. It will be used to hopefully place in suspension the remnants of plutonium and uranium that are bound at the Maralinga site. The other day we received results from the first test site at Maralinga. I am pleased to say that everything went well. Briefly, graphite rods are inserted into the pits where remnants of the plutonium and uranium remain along with steel and other material that was left over from the Maralinga tests. High voltage is generated into the soil. The result is that the soil, and hopefully everything else, turns to glass.

The specks of plutonium, which are dangerous if inhaled, and the uranium, which is toxic if held for any great time, are suspended in this substance. Once it cools, there is a glass substance which is very safe and solid and will hopefully remain in that situation forever. The process that has been developed is obviously working very well. I have great concerns about the decontamination, as has the Auditor-General. I hope that we can get some clear policy directions on it in the near future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Kemp), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996.

These amendments are government policy and should be allowed to proceed without delay. The amendments were announced as party policy during the election campaign and so have been available for comment and debate for at least four months. All parties—the Indigenous Land Corporation, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the opposition, the Greens and the Democrats—were aware of our intention to introduce them. There has been extensive consultation with the Indigenous Land Corporation and ATSIC in relation to their drafting. They will have an impact on the operations of the ILC, and it is better that they apply from the beginning rather than be grafted on later.

BREAK.PARA: These are not particularly contentious amendments. One of the amendments will allow individuals in particular circumstances to apply for land through the ILC. This is particularly important to Torres Strait Islanders, who tend toward individual rather than collective ownership. There has been extensive discussion with the ILC about this, as there were concerns on their part that this could lead to debate as to the relative importance of one individual as against another. But if there were provisions in the amendments, it would only be after extensive consultation and consideration and in exceptional circumstances.

I would like to ask the purpose of the opposition to the immediate progress of these amendments. If it is to allow further consideration and consultation, I believe that that is a nonsense. We have had at least four months for that. These measures have been known to all interested parties for at least that time. If there is a delay, there will be at least another four months before they can be introduced again. I urge that they be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the granting of an exemption to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. It does so on the basis of the terms and conditions of the Hill cut‐off motion. The cut‐off motion does not require the Senate to grant those concessions unless it has been demonstrated by the government that in each and every case there is an urgency about this bill, which the government has yet to do. It has not been able to demonstrate that there is an urgency. Advice given to me is that there has not been adequate consultation in terms of Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) would be aware of the terms of the Hill cut‐off motion, which provides for the orderly debate of bills on the basis that they provide opportunities for senators to adequately research the implications of bills and to allow for there to be public debate about controversial matters. I am advised that this bill is controversial. This proposition does not require immediate attention by this chamber. Given the fact that there has been inadequate consultation, it is the opposition's view that there ought to be further discussion within the community and further public debate about these matters.

As senators would be aware, the Aboriginal community is currently addressing a number of bills, such as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 1), and the Native Title Act. There is considerable public attention on the issues relating to Aboriginal affairs and accountability. In our judgment, it is not appropriate to try to push this piece of legislation through, given the consideration that is being given to these other pieces of legislation simultaneously.

The opposition does not take a bloody‐minded attitude towards the work within the Senate. If one looks at the list of bills that have been exempted from the Hill cut‐off motion, one will find that there have been 33 bills exempted to date. Only six bills, not including this one, have been refused exemption. It seems to me that, in those circumstances, the Senate has behaved responsibly and allowed for the proper consideration of government legislation. At the same time, it has allowed for adequate consultation to take place within the community at large.

In terms of the statement of reasons for the introduction and the passage of this bill in these sittings, I find the statement put down by the government to be totally inadequate. It is gobbledegook. When you read it, it does not tell you very much about what is being proposed. Minister, I suggest that you ask whomever it is who puts these together to write a little bit more clearly as to what you are intending to do with such pieces of legislation and why there is such an urgency. You have clearly not demonstrated that in the material put before this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Herron on this matter. At the outset I wish to say that I see no difference between this bill and other bills which have been exempted from the standing orders by the motion moved by Senator Chamarette.

PARA.BREAK: These amendments to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amend ment Bill (No. 2) 1996, as the Senate well knows, formed the subject of some inquiry last year. There was a select committee set up, commonly known as the land fund committee, which looked into the substantive part of these amendments. There are some other amendments included, but they are of a more technical nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I appreciate the concerns expressed by the opposition and, more particularly, by Senator Chamarette, about consultation, I say to the Senate that these matters were ventilated during the election campaign. They were part of our policy. They were ventilated during a comprehensive inquiry which Senator Chamarette and Senator Campbell, who is the chamber here today, took part in. It was one of the more thorough inquiries I have seen since my time in the Senate. Therefore, I would say the Aboriginal community is well aware of these proposed amendments. One amendment in particular, the question of vesting land in individuals, attracted a lot of attention.

If you do not deal with this bill now, we could face a delayed implementation in the order of four to six months. We would then have the ILC going about its business over the next financial year, starting on 1 July, and then amendments would be made to the legislation which governs its duties. The ILC would then have to change tack, as it were—not dramatically so but, nonetheless, it would have to change tack—in how it looks at certain things; for instance, in the granting of land or in the maintaining of land which has been granted to individuals. That is a departure from the current regime under which the ILC has to work.

I put to the Senate that it would be in the interests of the administration of this land fund if the ILC knew at the outset what it is going to be dealing with, rather than it being down the track in the financial year when these amendments come into play.

PARA.BREAK: The question of these amendments is relevant here because I believe they enjoy widespread support. The inquiry that took place last year showed that a lot of people wanted these amendments to take place. I believe the government is acting in a respon sible manner by trying to implement these as soon as it can. I congratulate Senator Herron for trying to address these concerns with such immediacy. Any obstruction of these amendments is really putting off the day when these amendments will be made law and depriving the Aboriginal community of the enjoyment that these benefits will bring.

SPEECH.PARA: For those reasons I urge the Senate to consider this matter. I urge, in particular, Senator Chamarette to reconsider her decision. I have spoken to Senator Chamarette and I understand that she has a problem of conviction in relation to this matter. There is really no ostensible reason that Senator Chamarette can see for exempting this legislation. I ask Senator Chamarette to bear in mind the points made by Senator Herron, myself and other speakers for the government in relation to the merits of having these amendments passed sooner rather than later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) do not support this motion to exempt the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 from the due process of scrutiny underlying the cut‐off motion. I do that with some regret because it was one of the earliest election promises of the then Leader of the Opposition, the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard), that this bill would be introduced upon his election and that the amendments that have been previously supported in the Senate would be brought in.

SPEECH.PARA: I might refresh people's memories of this. The bill we are considering at the moment contains aspects of the land fund bill which were passed by the Senate and then abandoned when they came back from the House of Representatives as a potential double dissolution trigger. At that time, Mr Howard in his previous role as the Leader of the Opposition announced that he would reintroduce the bill. I believe it would have been a dereliction of duty if we had not seen the bill reintroduced at this point in the proceedings of this parliament. However, people also know that I am committed to the idea of the cut‐off motion as `introduce one session, debate the next to allow for consultation'.

BREAK.PARA: I feel there has not been sufficient opportunity to allow for consultation on the matters that are contained within this bill. It may have been another matter if this bill had been introduced in the first week of the session and was due to come up for debate in the last week of the session. I feel the matters are somewhat similar, but they are not identical. I think that is the sticking point which I have.

I believe that Aboriginal communities which gave very considerable support to some of these measures when they were canvassed for their views by the two land fund committees that were looking at these areas may well have changed their view in the light of the months of operation of the ILC under its present arrangements.

An argument in support of that is that we are not seeing here a bill that contains the complete list of identical amendments as voted up in the Senate; we are seeing quite a number of changes. That is because circumstances have changed. Whereas I would have liked to have seen the extra $3 million for administration committed to the ILC to allow its operation not to intrude upon the amount that was available in terms of funding for acquisition and management, that is no longer in the bill. It is not there because—my understanding is—the ILC has notified the present government that it does not need that additional money for administrative costs. I find that amazing, but it is an illustration that the government too, because of its concerns about budget funding, et cetera, has, I think with relief, accepted that from the ILC very readily. That illustrates that matters have changed since the time this bill was passed in the Senate and then returned again following rejection.

I believe there has not been sufficient time between the introduction of this bill on Thursday last and today to debate it, having exempted it from the consultation that it deserves with the Aboriginal community. I think one of the unstated reasons for its urgency is that this is my last week in the Senate. The government would have been fairly confident that the items within that bill would have my support, and they would be right. I do not have queries with the content of the bill; but that is not the point. It would be blatantly hypocritical of me, having spent a lot of my time defending the cut-off motion as being democratic in its nature, to say that some bill that I particularly supported should come up for the simple reason that I would be able to vote for it.

So, while I do support most of the measures within that bill and express regret that I cannot agree to its exemption, I do not think there is any way in which I could agree to its not being laid aside in the Senate, having been introduced. I welcome its introduction. As I said before, the coalition would have been able to be criticised quite severely if it had not introduced it in this session. I welcome its introduction but I do not support the urgency of its being considered this week, in spite of the pleas made to me by Senator Ellison. I believe that the Aboriginal community should be consulted to see whether these measures are still measures which they would like introduced. If they are, I believe this chamber should give that due consideration and support it when it is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will not be supporting this exemption either, but we did support the exemption for the bill which relates to the ATSIC election being held in October. We thought the government made a reasonable case for why we should consider that bill now. I am mindful of what has been said by previous speakers. I agree with much of what has been said. There are changes in this bill, and those changes require consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: This really has come quickly upon us. We have not been appropriately warned ourselves, let alone Aboriginal communities, about the timing of the introduction of this bill. While we have been prepared to look at each bill on its merits, there is such a difference between what is proposed in the ATSIC bill No. 1 and in this bill that we cannot proceed hastily without being able to go back and ask Aboriginal communities, and the Senate, what they think about the changes between the first debate here, the committee stage, the Senate select committee, and the revisited recommendations of the Senate select committee. We could not do that this week. It would be very inappropriate to do it. We can wait until the next session without any problem at all, in my view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly put on the record my abject disappointment at the position taken by the opposition parties, but particularly the Greens. I must say, I was shocked to hear that this would not receive an exemption. When Senator Chamarette asked Senator Herron a question a fortnight ago about where this legislation was Senator Chamarette, either by way of interjection or by way of taking note—I do not recall just what it was—actually suggested to the Senate that this bill would not require an exemption. I think at some stage Senator Herron in his answer to Senator Chamarette during question time had said: `Why are you doing it? It does not need an exemption.' Today we have a different story.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Carr was probably not as closely involved in this debate. I know Senator Bob Collins, Senator Kernot, Senator Chamarette and Senator Ellison were very closely involved. It is absolute nonsense to say that there has not been consultation on this. I accept Senator Chamarette's view as one that certainly has some merit—to say that things might have changed in the last nine months on these issues. I suspect that in regard to the issues that are dealt with by this bill there would not have been any change at all because we have gone to the ones that circumstances have not changed. As I have said to Senator Chamarette privately, we went through the amendments that were listed in the select committee's report debated in this chamber. One of the amendments the Senate wanted was that the national strategy should be based on regional strategies. The majority of the Senate agreed that it should be a ground upwards process of determining a national strategy. The national strategy has been determined and tabled in this place. So clearly with that sort of amendment time has overtaken it. But Senator Herron, you will note, in his second reading speech said that we still think that principle is important and at the end of the review period we would still want to see whether or not the Senate majority was right in the first place and, indeed, the national strategies in future should be based on regional strategies. That is something I think a majority of senators would still agree on.

Crucial to this is overcoming the most hypocritical and sad change that the previous government made to this legislation. We all recall that when the native title legislation was debated in this place a reason for the establishment of the land fund was that the preamble to the native title bill, as it was—act as it is now—stated that a land fund would be established because it recognised that only a very small number of people would be able to benefit from native title. This land fund would be to help those people who had been `most severely dispossessed', to paraphrase it.

Effectively, what the land fund legislation did by entirely ignoring that principle that was enshrined in the preamble—the preamble that I think Senator Kernot called a marvellous, beautiful and wonderful statement—was erase that entire concept from the Native Title Act. The land fund legislation erased a significant section of that preamble that Senator Kernot described as a pristine, beautiful and marvellous statement.

Part of this legislation that we are seeking to deal with today reinstates a part of that principle, and that is to ensure that those people suffering most disadvantage in relation to access to land be given preference. Of course that was a contentious issue. We took that issue around Australia. We went to 12 different centres around Australia. We certainly did not consult with every Aboriginal person, but I do know that we consulted with a lot more people in a lot more detail than the previous government ever did in relation to any of its acts.

The concept of assisting those suffering most disadvantage in access to land was one that had actual general agreement—even the Peter Yus and the Noel Pearsons actually came up with this sort of wording to reach consensus at their crisis meeting. If you go back to the Hansard, you will note that, when Noel Pearson gave evidence to the committee in Cairns, he said, `Look, I think that's a good principle.' He agreed with the principle of consulting with traditional owners and those with historical links to the land. Noel agreed with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the same—
—No. This is another amendment dealt with under this amending bill, Senator Kernot, that we are seeking to—
—You ran them together.

—I will try and slow down and put a bit more punctuation into my speech. The concept that, when you go to buy some land for Aboriginal people, you actually do consult with those with traditional and historical links to the land was one that Noel Pearson in particular, and just about everyone, agreed with. There was virtually unanimous support for the concept.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason they opposed having it dealt with in the initial bill was that their position was quite a pragmatic one. When you are around Aboriginal affairs for a while—and I have only been around it for a little while—you do have to learn to be pragmatic and achieve what is achievable. Their view was, `We should get legislation; we do not want it held up.' They said, `Look, forget about all your amendments; you're holding up our bit of legislation that we need for social justice reasons.' They were saying, `Good amendments, Senator Campbell; good amendments, coalition parties; good amendments, Senator Chamarette; but stop making so much fuss about them. Just get the damned legislation through the Senate.' That was the approach.

The amendments that are contained in this bill are the ones that were entirely non-contentious to all bar Lois O'Donoghue and probably David Ross. When you left Canberra and went out to Dubbo, Brisbane, Cairns and Darwin, you found that all of these people wanted that. In this chamber, Senator Bob Collins said, `You cannot have individual ownership. That whole concept is absolutely anathema to Aboriginal people; it is not part of their culture.' I remember Senator Evans saying that you have to have this white man's concept of a corporation to reflect the cultural relationship between Aboriginal people and the land. But, funnily enough, when we got out to the goldfields, when we got up to Cairns and spoke to Torres Strait Islanders, we found a lot of Aboriginal people—not just Torres Strait Islanders but Aboriginals from the goldfields all around Australia—saying, `No, no, you cannot rule that out; it can happen. It is a possibility.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not saying it is universally supported now, are you?

—No. I am not saying it is universally supported. This is what we always argued, Senator Kernot. I find it—and the coalition supported me on this—racially discriminatory and paternalistic to say, `You've got to have our concept of how you own land. You've got to be a corporation.'

SPEECH.PARA: What this bill sought to do was to say, `Let's have some flexibility; let the Aboriginal people have some self- determination in relation to this question; let them have some power to determine how they live their lives and how they own their land—of course subject to the ILC.' You will notice in this bill that we very carefully ensured that, in exceptional circumstances, the ILC would have the right to make those grants without excluding them, based on their race.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it urgent?

—I will get to the reason it is urgent, Senator Kernot, and I will conclude on this point. We had that debate and we had that consultation. I will accept Senator Chamarette's point as to the result if the Senate votes this way. Senator Herron, in his travels during the winter recess, will, I am sure, consult on a whole range of Aboriginal affairs matters, and he will also consult on this so that Senator Chamarette's purpose will be served. It is an honourable purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: I had to say in this speech that I was shocked at the decision not to exempt it after our discussions prior to this date. The reason it is urgent is that we went through that consultation process. The coalition parties decided that we would not insist upon these amendments and that we would take the view we were pushing it uphill to get it through the Senate and would not get it through the Senate. We decided we would try and win the election. We decided that we would go to the election with our amendments written in black and white on a policy that was sent by the former shadow minister, Christine Gallus, who did a superb job distributing them to a huge number of Aboriginal communities. There was massive support.

The day that we decided to pursue that course, that is, to try and win the election and win a majority in the House of Representatives, the now Prime Minister and former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, got up in that place and said to the whole of Australia and everyone who took a very close interest in this bit of legislation, `We cannot get it through the Senate. Trying to get it through the Senate is not going to achieve our ends. Pursuing that course is the best way to achieve our ends and to achieve the wishes of all of those Aboriginal people who came in and supported us.' The support we got was absolutely phenomenal.

The network of people who have come to share the views of the coalition in relation to so many Aboriginal affairs matters was built up enormously during that process. I have met a lot of people who I regard as my friends in Aboriginal Australia through that process. They were horrified to know that we were not going to insist on the Senate getting the legislation through. I said to them, `We are going to win the election down there and, as soon as we can, we are going to bring this legislation back here. That is the promise of John Howard MP, the member for Bennelong, then the Leader of the Opposition—that, if he became Prime Minister, as soon as he could possibly do so, he would reintroduce the legislation into the Senate and try and get these amendments through.

That was the promise we made. I thought that that was very much something that Senator Chamarette understood. I regard it as a bit of a moot point as to whether we introduced the legislation a few weeks ago or introduced it now. As Senator Bob Collins would know, you cannot simply get a one- page policy document and turn it into a piece of legislation in about two minutes. It does take a little bit longer. Senator Herron is to be commended for the drive that he has brought to the process of bringing this legislation back in. I know this because I spoke to him within 48 hours of him becoming the minister. He has been determined to bring this bit of legislation into this place as soon as was physically and politically possible. He has got it through all the processes of the cabinet and brought it in here, and he is personally responsible for ensuring that the Prime Minister's promise is kept. It is just a great shame to me personally that, because of the failure of the Senate to grant it an exclusion from this exemption, it cannot be dealt with before this session is over.

As Senator Chamarette said before, she has lost her place in this chamber. I know that she has put a lot of time and energy into the quality and the detail of these amendments, so that is a matter of some regret. Clearly, she has strong principles in relation to the cut-off motion and community consultation. However, it is important to remember that we have carried out that consultation.

I will not prejudge what the Aboriginal views are because we will carry out that consultation, but I would be very surprised if they have changed one iota on the substantive matters that form part of this bill. They are matters of high principle for us and for many people in Aboriginal Australia. It is a great shame that we cannot deliver to them what I regard to be a crucial part of their social justice. But, again, it takes a long time to move things in a democracy the size of Australia. If we have to wait another five months to deliver what I regard as absolutely basic to their human rights—that is, ensuring they have freedom in relation to accessing land issues and not some paternalistic approach that tells them how they should own land—then we will wait a few more months. We look forward to the support of the Senate when that occurs.
