TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill on behalf of the opposition, I indicate we will be supporting the legislation. The government has decided to proceed with legislation similar to that introduced into the House last year by the former government. This bill is not controversial. The development allowance is a well‐targeted and effective initiative introduced by us when we were in government. It was announced in the One Nation statement and was successful in its objective of giving Australia a more competitive investment environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The allowance is administered by the Development Allowance Authority, which is a statutory authority operating within the Treasurer's portfolio. I wonder whether Senator Short has heard of it. He should have, because on 17 June 1992 he informed the Senate—I refer to page 3841 of the Hansard—that the opposition would oppose the establishment of the authority, and then he, as part of the then opposition, voted against it. I would like to very briefly quote Senator Short. On 17 June 1992 he said:

I will very quickly outline again why we are opposed to the Development Allowance Authority Bill and the Pooled Development Funds Bill. The Development Allowance Authority Bill establishes a one‐member statutory authority—the Development Allowance Authority, the DAA—which will have the task of assessing the eligibility of large projects with a capital cost of $50m or more. The basic objection that we have to this is that no earthly reason has been presented as to why we have to set up yet another quango to handle a matter such as this.

I do not know whether Senator Short intends to speak on the legislation on behalf of the government, but I am pleased to see that now, four years later, those opposite have been converted on yet another issue and are in fact proposing legislation very similar to that which we put forward last year in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill is a small bill, as Senator Sherry said, to extend the development allowance tax concessions to a wider group of people. The financial impact of this bill is to increase the amount of revenue forgone as infrastructure concessions by about $92 million over nine years, or about $10 million a year. The bill removes certain restrictions on the restructuring of the ownership of projects eligible for the development allowance, and the amendments will allow the transfer of the allowance benefit where ownership of a project is transferred to another entity or to another type of entity structure before the application was registered.

SPEECH.PARA: The development allowance was one of the initiatives of the 1992 One Nation package designed to encourage business investment in new plant. Senator Sherry made some comments about it being well targeted. We agree that it was probably necessary at the time, but look at what has happened over the last few years in this whole area. Powered by the development allowance, the investment allowance and accelerated depreciation provisions, private sector capital investment has picked up significantly in recent years. That is what it was designed to do. To that extent, it has worked.

According to the OECD, private sector non-residential investment picked up by 15.2 per cent in 1994 and 9.5 per cent in 1995, and it is projected to rise by 9.9 per cent in 1996 and a further 14.2 per cent in 1997. In the five years from 1993, Australia's capital formation will have grown by the second highest rate in the OECD. Considering the OECD is forecasting strong economic growth in 1996-97 and beyond, I think we should be asking how appropriate it is for this to be widened even a little bit. Is it necessary?

The figures that I quoted previously about how capital formation has picked up in the five years from 1993 show that the counter‐cyclical measures that were needed in 1992 to kick‐start the economy, like the development allowance and cutting sales tax on cars, were basically successful, but we would argue that they are no longer needed. So from a macro‐economic point of view I really question the need for this bill.

BREAK.PARA: Also, with the budget under pressure, we should question whether we should be extending tax concessions which have outlived their usefulness. The development allowance can be added to the list of business welfare. It is surprising that this government has chosen to bring this particular piece of welfare forward at the same time as it is changing or dismantling the export markets development grant and the development import finance facility.

But I think you can contrast this with the issue of infrastructure borrowing concessions, and they are also governed by the Development Allowance Authority. This borrowing concession—which is supposed to encourage private sector investors to get into infrastructure; they are not doing anything about that—remains current.

This bill is a technical bill seeking to clarify some aspects of the Development Allowance Authority which were not clear in 1992. But I think the government should have a long, hard look at the activities of the Development Allowance Authority in the area of infrastructure borrowing concessions when it looks at its budget in August.

The Australian newspaper's national affairs editor, Mike Steketee, described the infrastructure concession as a much worse rort than the government sales tax exemption which had Mr Costello so outraged a few weeks ago. What was Mr Costello's response? This is Mr Costello who a few months ago accused the states of unjustified rorts and promised to attack rorts in the system. Earlier today the same Mr Costello announced that, instead of tightening up the infrastructure borrowings concession, he is going to extend it. He is going to ignore all the expert opinion about what it costs the budget. He is going to reinstate the concession for urban roads.

Last year in this debate the Australian Democrats tried to draw attention to the role that the infrastructure borrowing concession has played in subsidising, in our view, entirely inappropriate infrastructure projects such as City Link in Melbourne. These projects enjoy not only a federal tax concession but also often a wide range of benefits from the states. And for what? What do we taxpayers get back for this?

The former Prime Minister requested EPAC to look at the effect of private sector investment in infrastructure. EPAC, in its private infrastructure task force release last October, concluded that there was little efficiency to be gained from private ownership of roads and that private financed projects are `likely to be least advantageous for urban roads'. It also concluded that the cost of building private roads was inflated, because of legal and financial complexities and network risk where the viability of the project is affected by decisions on competing roads and public transport.

In response to that, the former Treasurer, Mr Willis, last December, in responding to what he described as widespread community concerns about the City Link and M2 projects, removed the borrowing concession. He said, `I hear what you're saying about the benefits the private sector is getting; double benefits that are doubly inappropriate.'

But today Mr Costello has announced that roads will get their concession back. We do not believe there is any good economic or commercial reason for this. Tollways in New South Wales, in Victoria and in Queensland have proven to be excessively profitable without the concession. This is an appalling case of business welfare and it is appallingly targeted. In the committee stage I will move the amendment which has been distributed and deal with it then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to participate in the debate on the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill because it provides an opportunity to further encourage investment in Australia to improve the standard of our infrastructure. This bill will streamline the applications for development allowances. It will reduce the obstacles that have been put in front of investors when seeking government assistance for development in major development projects.

SPEECH.PARA: The essential criteria in the principal act of 1992 must still be met. The purpose for the allowance will not be changed, but the opportunity for investors to benefit from the allowance will be enhanced. What this bill is doing is merely changing the eligibility criteria. Where all other criteria in the principal act have been met by the applicant, this bill will allow the benefits granted by the Development Allowance Authority to be transferred in certain circumstances.

This amendment will operate where there has been a transfer of ownership after the application for the development allowance has been made. It will also operate in situations where the project is now owned by another entity type structure and the ownership was transferred after the application had been made but before the registration of the allowance.

To assist business the act will apply retrospectively. I am not one, as this Senate well knows, to support retrospectivity when it means placing obligations on taxpayers for circumstances which operated in the past and whose legality has since been changed. But in this case applications for the allowance closed on 1 January 1993, so it is vital that there is retrospective application in this particular case because it is retrospective legislation not in respect of a tax but in respect of a benefit.

However, the development authority will be given the power to decide whether an application has lapsed in particular circumstances. Those applications for plant expenditure which were refused or only partially granted, because ownership of the project had been transferred, will be reconsidered under this amendment.

I know that my honourable colleagues will be asking how much the application of this Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill will cost, and so they should. That is a perfectly legitimate question. I am delighted to say that it will cost the government no extra revenue in the sense that revenue has already been incorporated into the budget figures. So there will be no extra budgetary implications.

On the other hand, the benefits to successful applicants will be substantial. Some $10 million in one year will be available to applicants who will now be successful because of these amendments. For the extent of the operation of the allowance—that is, from 1993-94 to the financial year 2001-02—successful project applications would benefit by approximately $92 million. That is a substantial amount even in terms of major industrial projects. It will be ordinary Australians who will ultimately benefit from employment opportunities and using the facilities once those facilities are completed.

The Development Allowance Authority was set up to increase investment in Australia. When it was set up in 1992 its aim was to improve Australia's international competitiveness, through the application of tax incentive schemes, to increase investment for infrastructure by the private sector and to accelerate investment in major industrial projects. The allowance could also be used for investment in labour relation reforms and input pricing.

Up to the end of the 1994-95 financial year, all the projects had been for infrastructure in New South Wales. The projects which have been certified are: the M2 motorway in north western Sydney—I wonder whether that comes within the ambit of the Democrat's amendment; the electricity cogeneration plant in Smithfield, Sydney; a water treatment plant and water supply for the Illawarra district of south of Sydney; and the light rail system and related facilities between Ultimo and Pyrmont in Sydney.

There have been over 500 applications for the allowance, 250 of which were registered by 30 June 1995. These represented a capital expenditure of well over $100 million through to 2002. The mining and manufacturing sectors are the greatest beneficiaries and great employment generators. While 11 projects, which have been registered, involve expenditure of over $1 billion each, the largest single registered project involves almost $5 billion.

I believe that the time is right for a more detailed examination of investment in Australian infrastructure. These types of long-term projects are ideal investments for superannuation funds. For example, the AMP Society is pioneering investments such as these. The present level of superannuation savings has now exceeded $240 billion and is likely to rise to some $2,000 billion by 2020. This amount of $2,000 billion will largely be the result of an increasing level of compulsory contribution and the ageing population. Unless we are very vigilant in using this money to extend infrastructure type projects on a voluntary basis, much of this superannuation money could well end up overseas if we are not careful.

What we need to do is make it attractive to investors, particularly superannuation funds, to put their money into Australian projects. We need to encourage them to keep their money in Australia by giving them incentives rather than dictating to them. It does not have to be legislated for and it should not be made compulsory. But irresistible options should be offered to people and their superannuation funds to have appropriate products, such as those I have just described, available and as such ensure that super funds make a valuable contribution to the Australian economy.

As a response to business and industry groups, the previous government had legislation to effect these sorts of changes. The House of Representatives passed all stages of a similar bill in 1995, but because of the backlog of legislation in the House it was not passed before the parliament was prorogued prior to the election.

Business and industry representatives have rightly called for a review of the eligibility criteria. With the passage of this bill, all types of project restructuring of a bona fide nature will be able to go ahead while retaining the rights of project managers or joint developers to the development allowance. The government is treating the removal of some restrictions on the restructuring of ownership, which had previously jeopardised eligibility for the allowance, as a matter of high priority. Here is another commitment delivered by this government. The bill previously enjoyed bipartisan support. I commend this bill to all senators because it will increase the benefits of the incentive scheme to investors in Australian infrastructure and will therefore be of long-term benefit to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1996. I might say at the beginning that the purpose of the amending bill has been ably explained by Senator Sherry and, within my hearing, Senator Kernot. The purpose is fully set out in the explanatory memorandum and the bill itself. I do not intend to make a recitation in my remarks of what the purpose of this bill is, save to say that it focuses the development allowance more effectively and sharpens its focus so that it goes more efficiently to the intended groups.

SPEECH.PARA: I also think it is probably necessary to record, as Senator Sherry did, that the minister with notional authority for this bill in this chamber is the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short. When the former government introduced this bill—indeed this bill is a direct copy of the bill introduced by the former Labor government—Senator Short saw fit to oppose it. Now he is the minister bringing it forward. The irony ought not be lost that the terrible things that the former government did are, at least in this theatre, being promoted by the existing government. As Senator Watson just said, this bill has served a very worthwhile purpose and continues to do so.

The development allowance and the authority that the development allowance spawned was a measure introduced by the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, in 1992 when he brought down his trail blazing One Nation statement. In economic terms it is a countercyclical measure to stimulate the economy to provide an incentive for major projects to claim further advantage on the depreciation of plant and equipment and to reinvest in projects of a significant size.

The development allowance itself no longer operates but the projects it spawned still make a significant contribution to the economy. The initial purpose of the legislation, therefore, was achieved. It brought forward a huge number of major mining and infrastructure developments around the country which otherwise would have languished on the back burner longer than economically desirable.

The upsurge in demand created by those major projects brought about more employment and, because of the multiplier effect of those projects in the broader economy, orders were placed with companies hanging off the supply of materials, plant and equipment for those projects. As a classical Keynesian counter‐cyclical measure, the development allowance scheme worked, and that has been a matter for comment on all sides of the chamber. This bill is necessary to focus that measure further.

The government's support of this bill gives rise, to put it at its mildest, to a quizzical question from industry about the government's approach to industry support mechanisms. The development allowance and the continuation of the Development Allowance Authority is clearly a government program to support further economic and industrial development in Australia. To that extent, we know that, at least in that area, the government supports this initiative. But let's consider the development import finance facility scheme, better known as DIFF.

We know that the government is chopping the DIFF scheme, a scheme in which a host of Australian companies have millions of dollars tied up in developments with overseas companies. The soft loans authorised by the Australian government under the DIFF scheme went into aid type programs in developing countries and to generate growth in those developing countries. But it was Australian entrepreneurs who, given the support of the DIFF scheme, won the contracts that would create an advantage in our economy and a market for the export of infrastructure development skills and other skills—notably green DIFF industry skills in environmental technology—in developing countries. On one hand, the government continues the development allowance scheme; on the other, in an area of vital export earning power for Australia, it chops off a scheme that has served the nation well.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you, like me, are a senator representing Western Australia. One of Western Australia's most famous companies, Clough Engineering, has been a great beneficiary of the DIFF scheme and won initial contracts in Indonesia for major engineering works. Now, the scheme which helped that company to grow and to become more internationally competitive—winning contracts without the advantage of soft loans for development, winning contracts on its own merits throughout the booming Asia‐Pacific area—is to be chopped off while the development allowance scheme is to continue.

We know that the government also has on the chopping block the export market development grant scheme. A bill referring to that scheme came through the Senate in the last sitting week. That scheme repays small and medium‐sized Australian companies, at a lesser amount than the actual cost, the costs incurred in developing new export markets for their goods and services. That scheme is to be put under the knife by the razor gang known as the ERC. Industry has lined up in a long queue, along with all of the industry associations, the names of which are nationally famous, to oppose the removal of the EMDG scheme.

We also know that a number of other industry schemes, under the broad heading of AusIndustry, provide help and assistance in a range of ways: through research and development incentives; through discovering the best and most appropriate technology for their needs and at a lower cost to them; and through helping small to medium‐sized companies prepare their own market strategies and corporate plans.

But the AusIndustry schemes are to be chopped substantially as well, and all in the interests of chasing what the media have dubbed the `illusory black hole'. Really, it is in the interests of pursuing this government's ideological obsession about small government. On the way to that goal, it is chopping off valuable schemes with proven and refereed track records of assistance to industry. A mixed message is emanating from this government about what it does and does not support in the industry sector. Many industry figures ask me what I think will happen with various schemes. Witness, for example, the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

At a meeting of the National Farmer's Federation just over a month ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in response to some intense questioning from the floor, gave a wink and a nod to the federation, indicating that the diesel fuel rebate scheme would continue for them, as would the 150 per cent tax reduction for rural research and development. The two questions put to the Prime Minister were about that. The media widely reported his remarks as meaning that, because of the loss of votes in the New South Wales state by‐election from the National Party to the Labor Party, and because of rural unrest over the gun issue, the government had moved to mend its fences, giving a wink and a nod to the rural industry.

then what about all the other industries that have schemes on the chopping block that do not have that sort of political clout or political urgency that the federal government recognises in one sector? What about the other sectors that a wink and a nod does an injustice to? For example, I have received—as I am sure you, Madam Acting Deputy President Knowles, as a Western Australian senator, would have received—a whole host of submissions from the mining industry about the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Is it going to continue for that industry?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have been listening very patiently to Senator Cook for 10 minutes. This is not an omnibus bill; this is the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill. Senator Cook should not be giving us an omnibus speech. Perhaps you might be kind enough to suggest a little bit more relevance in the reminder of his contribution.
—Senator Cook, could I suggest exactly that, that you remain relevant to the bill before us.

—My point of relevance is that this bill gives a positive signal to industry, as far as the development allowance is concerned, while industry is receiving negative signals across a range of other areas in which there are proven programs of industry assistance which increase our exports, reduce our current account deficit, create jobs for Australians and create, by virtue of Australian companies making profits, reinvestment in Australian industry. Therefore, those schemes should be seen as positive. But I have made that point.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with my parliamentary colleague, the shadow minister for finance, Senator Sherry, and indicate that the opposition will support this bill because it is, as we have said, a bill which we put up in government, and in order to be consistent we will pursue its merits in opposition as well. It does provide some necessary changes to this scheme.

I ask the government to give some thought to unscrambling the message that it is sending to Australian industry. It should give clear, long, strong signals to Australian industry as to what the framework of its industry programs might be because Australian industry depends on many of those programs to provide competitiveness. Given that the Australian economy is now more internationalised than ever before—international corporations compete against Australian companies within our domestic economy and we compete through Australian companies on the international stage as well—in order to generate investment and longer term planning by companies, strong signals that are going to ensure that companies can raise investment capital against are necessary.

At the present time, I do commend this bill, but I also note that the signal is extraordinarily mixed, and this is leading to a loss of confidence. Not surprisingly, the ACCI‐Westpac industry trend survey released on the weekend points to lower investment by Australian industry than anticipated. That will come back to haunt the government. I commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak to the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1996 at this stage. There are issues in relation to the Development Allowance Authority grant which are of concern to the Greens (WA). They include the type of privately funded infrastructure that we are asking taxpayers to support. One in particular is dealt with on page 7 of the Development Allowance Authority annual report. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Goal 1: increase private investment in publicly accessible infrastructure by means of the Develop Australia Bonds tax incentive.

The concern here is that we have known for some time that the previous government promised to provide tax incentives for private investment in public infrastructure, and that included electricity generation. In Western Australia the Greens were concerned that it seemed to be very carefully designed to include investment in the Collie power station. For various reasons, we thought this was sending a very wrong signal in relation to what it was that we were going to encourage—that is, to subsidise. It might be useful to find out whether or not the applications include coal fired power stations because it would be a great concern if that is what we are doing—not only not moving towards any real greenhouse goals in Australia but actually providing a public subsidy for privately funded coal fired power stations.

There are, however, some useful projects, including the certificates for a light rail system, but I join with the Australian Democrats in raising concern about this kind of public funding going to tollways. I believe that that is the wrong use of funding. I indicate at this stage that the Greens are prepared to support the amendments proposed by Senate Kernot for the Democrats in relation to the inappropriate nature of that use of public funding.

There have been some things that are okay. There has been funding for privately owned co‐generation power stations, although I must say in Western Australia the argument has been put in relation to power stations that co‐generation is an addition to anything governments are doing; therefore it means that people have an excuse to sell more power. If state and federal governments are working to assist in these plans, they should be looking into demand management strategies which look at how we use those sectors.

Governments have a role to play. They should not be cutting off one policy area from another. I do think we ought to have some goals about what is going on here. There are some relatively good things. It was announced today that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, has reinstated tax breaks for urban road projects, reversing a decision by the Keating government. Basically, tollways will be promoted; private funding for roads will be promoted. People will be charged a toll for something they have already paid for in lots of ways. I do not think it is acceptable. As I said, I will support the Democrats amendments.

We supposedly have some greenhouse commitments in Australia. I would like the parliamentary secretary to indicate whether the private infrastructure bonds, as announced by the previous government, will be made available for privately funded infrastructure such as the Collie power station. Or is that off the agenda?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GIBSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill amends the principal act, the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992. The purpose of this amending bill is to allow a restructuring, basically, of ownership of projects that have applied for this assistance which was offered by the previous government for the calendar year 1992, as explained to the Senate previously. That window of opportunity was available for 12 months for projects of over $50 million each. The benefit offered was a 10 per cent deduction of the capital cost over a 10‐year period.

SPEECH.PARA: As my colleague Senator Watson said, there were about 500 applications during that 12‐month period and there have been some minor extensions. At this stage, the department advises me that it has about 350 projects; but a time line is now approaching very fast—the prequalification application has to be in by the end of July.

There are about 350 projects, something like 10 per cent of which approached the previous government and, with bipartisan support, we backed the idea that the restructuring of the ownership of these projects—which had nothing to do with the actual project itself, but just who owned what bits of it—should not disqualify them from getting this allowance. TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor opposition will be supporting the amendments circulated by Senator Kernot for the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter came on at very short notice. In indicating our support for the amendments, we are being consistent with the position announced by the former Treasurer, Mr Willis, and the former Minister for Transport, Laurie Brereton, on 15 December last year, when it was made clear that the decision taken then followed the findings of the Economic Planning Advisory Council—commonly known as EPAC—private infrastructure task force report released in October which stated that private finance is `likely to be least advantageous for urban roads'.

Despite its general support for private infrastructure projects, the EPAC task force found that little efficiency was to be gained from private ownership of roads. It also concluded that the cost of building private roads was inflated because of legal and financial complexities and network risk where the viability of the project is affected by decisions on competing roads and public transport.

My attention has also been drawn to a more latter report—that of the National Commission of Audit. I refer to pages 295 and 296 of the report. Indeed, today we asked a question on this section in which the government has very firmly pronounced that it will be adopting a charter of budget honesty. In respect to tax expenditures, it says:

One area where current budget reporting is clearly inadequate is the cost of tax concessions (that is tax expenditures). Treasury noted that a forthcoming OECD publication shows that Australian reporting of tax expenditures currently falls short of overseas best practice.
The different budgetary processes that apply to tax concessions and expenditure programs in Australia have contributed to the lack of transparency of tax expenditure reporting.
Then it gives a number of reasons and concerns about this issue of tax concessions. The final reason given is as follows:
. . . procedures exist for the Department of Finance and the responsible portfolio to examine ways of containing blowouts in program expenditure but not blowouts in tax concessions.

As a result of all these factors, tax concessions are a largely non‐transparent form of assistance. This lack of transparency makes less visible the effect of tax concessions on the budget and reduces accountability. It also increases the likelihood that poorly targeted concessions will remain on offer.

We are being consistent in our approach in this area of roads and in the way tax concessions are targeted. The National Commission of Audit report, made available on Friday, was available to the government prior to the introduction of this legislation. For the reasons I have outlined—I could speak for longer on this matter, but that essentially sums up the position of the Labor opposition—we will be supporting the amendments the Democrats have circulated in the chamber to this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT

Senator Sherry has told us of the Labor Party's attitude, as stated by previous Treasurer Willis in December last year. I have that press release, too. On the second page of the press release Mr Willis gave two examples. In the case of the City Link project, he said:

BREAK.PARA: The federal government has already criticised the Kennett government for corralling traffic onto toll roads to boost the private developer's revenue as well as the application of a toll to the currently toll‐free Tullamarine freeway.

. . . for compensation to be paid to the tollway developer in the event of competition from future development of public transport services.

SPEECH.PARA: The City Link project in Melbourne is the best example of which I am aware of just how much impact a project can have on a community. The point has been demonstrated again and again. TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this measure, which flows from an inquiry which I set up when I was immigration minister just a few months ago. DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking to this bill when it was last dealt with in the Senate, I was talking about some of the issues which were involved. A number of people who gave evidence to the inquiry into this bill expressed concern about the nature of the operations of Wool International.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I was concerned initially with the fact that a precedent was being set in relation to the disallowable instrument, in that decisions were being made by Wool International about operations. For instance, the new body which was to be set up on the futures market would be disallowable, but the decision was to reduce that to three days notice. I thought that was a slippery slope in relation to parliamentary scrutiny.

However, one of the issues that became clear was that the nature of the operations that Wool International Holdings would be participating in might be used at some stage to point the finger at the Senate—that is, in relation to whether or not the Senate was responsible for Wool International being able to make decisions on the futures market. I think our concerns with this go further than that. We are concerned with the fact that:

Wool International is to be given power to undertake, through a subsidiary such as Wool International Holdings, wool marketing activities, includ ing forward trading and the use of futures and currency contracts for hedging purposes.

I point out that the Greens have generally opposed public companies moving into hedging and speculation and that such speculative activities are some of the avowed purposes of Wool International Holdings.

That these operations would be funded by what in fact is a compulsory levy is also of particular concern. Leaving aside voluntary levies, if you have a compulsory levy and under that levy you have a body engaged in market speculation, who then becomes financially and legally responsible if bad decisions are made? Nobody can tell me that a body operating in this market will be insulated from poor decisions.

I know there is the issue of defusing risk, but entering the speculative sphere and dealing in currency, futures and other speculative areas is problematic. Ignoring the fact that speculation is risk, even if you speculated in enough areas and the right areas to defuse the risk of currency fluctuation speculation, futures speculation and natural variation in commodity markets, you are still doing something other than the promotion of wool sales. You are also ultimately doing something which further adds to the instability of many aspects of the global economic system. We are simply adding to speculation and making speculation into standard business practice.

Basically, it is a problem. I think it is a problem if we as a Senate are being asked to require wool growers to be indirectly involved in the speculative market—that is, non-real things, what might happen in the future—and gambling using a public levy. Therefore, I have circulated an amendment—people will either have it already or get it soon—to remove mention of this extra company within Wool International so that the Senate will not be asked to sanction, to approve or to disapprove of speculative investments by a company which will be far removed from political scrutiny in reality.

We believe this is the wrong way to go. Just because the speculative economy internationally is getting big, it does not mean to say that, first, we should get involved with it in this way and that, second, we should require wool growers to be involved. Quite frankly, a growing number of wool growers are very unhappy with this. Certainly in Western Australia that number is large and is growing. I believe it is the wrong thing to do. In that sense, we will be putting our amendment in the committee stage of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1), which is before us. Being part of a family wool growing operation, I declare an interest. The current situation in the wool industry is of grave concern to all of us in this chamber and to many people in the Australian community. I say that because the wool industry has for so long underpinned the total social fabric, social structure, economic fabric and economic structure of so much of Australia. Other industries, whether they be grain growing or beef producing—and in a sense this even applies to a lot of mining operations—have benefited from investment in the wool industry which has provided shops, services, transport and the various things that go with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The hearings we held relating to the legislation before us concentrated primarily on one issue: the establishment of Wool International Holdings, the proposition we have before the Senate now. I want to make a number of things clear in terms of this piece of legislation. In my view, in a lot of senses it is a very strange piece of legislation—it emanated from the previous government—in that the Wool International Holdings proposals can only be termed as enabling legislation. It allows a proposal to come before the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) for the possible development of a scheme which deals with various options for marketing wool—whether it be through the futures market, through forward selling or through matching or combining growers' clips.

In essence, that does not sound like a bad concept but I am sceptical about whether or not it will ever eventuate—and I await the proposal with interest. The proposal was supposed to be before the minister in time for introduction on 1 July, or the coming wool selling season. As yet, no proposal has been put forward. We can talk about this proposal and certain aspects of it, such as what it might or might not be or what it may or may not do, until the cows come home, but the reality is that until such time as we see that proposal we have nothing before us in this chamber—nor does the minister, the government or anybody else for that matter.

Various witnesses made a lot of comments on the proposal, and many comments have been made outside the inquiry by people involved in the industry, whether it be through growing directly or through the chain of events that occur in getting wool to the marketplace and then exported. I find it rather interesting—in fact, I find it frustrating—that we have so many experts with so much knowledge about a proposal when in fact there is no proposal. It is quite amazing how people can come into this place and talk for so long about this so‐called proposal when there is no proposal. I wanted to make that point tonight.

I want to make a couple of other things very clear. A number of people who appeared before us expressed what the proposal might be. No‐one from any of the industry organisations who gave evidence said that they were opposed to the proposal of Wool International putting forward a plan. We did have some variations of what may or may not be contained in that particular plan. For example, in relation to the pastoralists and graziers of Western Australia—and a lot of publicity has come out of Western Australia in terms of this piece of legislation we have before us, particularly with regard to Wool International Holdings—I asked Mrs Lyn Johnson directly, `Are you opposed to the formation of Wool International Holdings?' I do not have her exact words in front of me, but in essence she said, `No, we're not opposed to it; but it must be a fully floated commercial company.' That is what she said.

The Western Australian Farmers Federation said, `If there is $24 million to come out of growers funds or to be supplemented by growers funds, then that must be in the form of a loan with a government guarantee.' The position given to us by the South Australian Farmers Federation was not dissimilar to the position of the Western Australian Farmers Federation. When we listened to organisations in Victoria, Queensland and New South Wales—I think I can add Tasmania, because the President of the Wool Council is a Tasmanian—they all said that they supported what is generally the popular version of what may or may not come forward in due course from Wool International Holdings.

With all the speculation, the comments, the criticisms and the claims that have been made around the place that politicians—particularly members of the Senate, me included—have come down on a particular position as far as any proposal from Wool International Holdings is concerned is an absolute nonsense. Until such time as we see that proposal, it comes to the minister and then goes back to the House of Representatives and this place through a disallowable instrument, which was an addition we included in the legislation, I have to say again and again that we have no proposal on which to make a judgment.

There was some criticism of Wool International not appearing before the committee. I want to make a couple of points on that which have already been made by others here. Wool International were there on the first day. They put a submission in. They did speak to me, as chairman of the committee, after the first day. This is on the public record, but I think it bears repeating. We did discuss it and I said, `It's entirely up to you people whether you appear or not. I would prefer that you did, but at the very least I would expect you to reply to the criticisms and the claims that have been made.'

They chose a particular route to do that and to not appear before the committee. I respect that as their right and I put no pressure on them whatsoever. But I think they made a mistake. I think it would have been very useful if they had voluntarily appeared. Nonetheless, as I think Senator Bob Collins said before the debate finished the other day, they were there and any one of us could have called them before the committee had we so chosen.

We also had a recommendation in this report to, in essence, bring attention to the concerns of many of the people who appeared before the committee with regard to the lack of confidence in Wool International and their wool selling policies. I would like to think that there were some magic wand we could utilise in their selling policies which would see a significant change in the market situation; but I do not believe there is.

There could be some room for a marginally different approach to the way it is being handled. But, at the end of the day, the thing that is cruelling the market at this time is that lack of confidence which emanates from the overhang of the stockpile over the market. If the government continued to deliver the government guarantee, I would certainly fight for it if there were a suspension of sales. But any move made to not continue the reduction of the stockpile in some form or another would create a situation where the pain would continue longer than it otherwise might need to.

As well as the round table conference held by the minister there is the development of targeted promotion, certainly some developments of options in marketing and the situations now occurring in the economies of Japan, Italy and in particular Germany. I believe that the impact of the unification of Germany is only just coming home to roost—the cost of that to the German people and the impact that has flowed through into such commodities as wool or apparel fibres. It is not only the wool industry that is finding things a little difficult at the moment. If we look right down the whole clothing, manufacturing and apparel fibre market we see that things are not as serious as they are for many woolgrowers but they certainly are not good.

As we work through this, we move towards the next round table conference of the industry. This chamber and this parliament has a real challenge in how we will administer the reports that will come back to Minister Anderson and how we will deal with particular issues before us. I must emphasise, as has already been said in this debate, that it is absolutely crucial that any announcement to the selling policies and the operations which will exist after 1 July 1997 be made very quickly. The biggest fear that the `trade' has of people who are involved in the buying, the selling and the processing of wool is the uncertainty of what might occur after that date.

We must also acknowledge in this debate that when looking at the debates that were held in this place after the 1990 and 1993 elections, the majority of pundits and commentators spelt out doom and gloom. They spelt out—and I am not saying this is good—that we would be looking at a tax on the wool industry in the vicinity of nine, 10 or 12 per cent. This legislation seeks to remove the tax on wool, which is currently 4.5 per cent. The impact of the removal of that tax will be somewhere in the order of 25 to 30 bales of wool. In simple terms, that means somebody who produces 100 bales of wool will receive an additional $2,500 to $3,000.

Some people in the press and others have raised issues with me regarding the removal of that tax. There was not one woolgrower who contacted me prior to the hearings and in the lead‐up to the election who wanted anything other than the removal of that tax. TALK.START.PARA: —In earlier centuries, the profession of teacher was greatly valued. The status of the teacher was very high, and deservedly so. The teacher's influence extended well beyond the classrooms into the whole community.

SPEECH.PARA: The word `education', in its root derivation, means a drawing out—not just a drawing out of facts and figures, but the development of the potential of each individual: the spiritual, moral, intellectual, physical and cultural attributes which are latent in all. A well-known educator recently said:

A liberal education presupposes free spirits and we must continually re‐affirm that education at all levels is primarily concerned with critical reflection, personal development and sustained inquiry involving the body, the mind, the feelings, the imagination, the fantasy life and above all, the life of spirit.

Throughout history, there have been great teachers who have imparted and treasured the knowledge and values of their societies. And today there are also some great teachers, however unsung and undervalued. That same educator said:
It is difficult to define a great teacher. Largeness of heart is characteristic, generosity and love of mankind. The successful teacher draws on underground reservoirs of vigour.

One such great Australian teacher is Rod West, the retiring headmaster of Trinity Grammar School, a man greatly admired for his outstanding qualities as an educator and as a humanitarian who also happens to be the source of my earlier quotations.

Rod West has had a profound influence on the lives of tens of thousands of students and, indeed, upon their parents. A fine Christian in every sense, he is a warm, friendly, compassionate leader whose genuine affection for his fellow beings is manifest in his every word and action.A moral philosopher with a rare gift of communication and expression, his message tinged with a gentle sense of humour, who draws often on the magic storehouse of English poetry to illustrate his values.

In our 20th century attitudes, leadership is usually measured in contributions to commerce, industry, science, politics and defence service. Sadly, we greatly underestimate the qualities and influence of the true teacher. We tend to measure our resources in the physical things around us—our minerals, agricultural potential, climate, land mass and rainfall. But there is one predominant resource which we frequently undervalue in its potential, the individual human.

It is the true teacher who can unlock the individual potential, who can impart values as well as a love of learning—above all who can inspire motivation and curiosity, who can beckon on. Was it Robert Browning who wrote:
Oh, that a man's reach should exceed his grasp
On what's a heaven for?

That seems to me to express Rod West's philosophy and his remarkable strivings in the interests of the betterment of mankind. And in all his life's work, he has been supported and encouraged by a devoted and understanding wife, Janet, whose contribution deserves full recognition.
Our schooldays—our formative years—are often the most important of our lives. There are great riches in their memories. Thoreau records this entry in his diary for 16 July 1851:

I think that no experience which I have today comes up to or is comparable with the experiences of my boyhood. My life was ecstasy. In youth, before I lost any of my senses, I can remember that I was all alive and inhabited my body with inexpressible satisfaction; both its weariness and its refreshment were sweet to me.
Thank you Rod for your great leadership, for beckoning on so many parents and students. Thank you for nurturing that inexpressible satisfaction in so many.
On the North Door of St Paul's Cathedral in London is a Latin inscription, a tribute to Sir Christopher Wren by his son. It says simply:
If you would seek his monument, look around you.
There are tens of thousands of living monuments to Rod West who well exemplifies Polonius' advice:
And this above all to thine own self be true.
If during my career in public life I make one-tenth of the contribution to society that Rod has made, I will consider myself a very fortunate man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to draw the Senate's attention to a rather unique report that I had the pleasure of launching a couple of weeks ago. It is entitled, `Youth Answers ' and it is unique because it is about the Aberfoyle Park and Happy Valley community in South Australia which actually commissioned five young Australians to consult their peers, that is, young people around the ages of 13 to 25, about health issues and the community needs of their environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Most research, including the Australian Democrats youth poll that we conduct every year where we ask young Australians about the issues affecting them, shows that young people believe that they do not have enough opportunities to have a say in the decision making processes in this country. Nor do they get a chance to be actively involved in the community and health needs of their society.

So I draw the Senate's attention to some of the recommendations in this report; but first I should note its cost. For nine months these young people spoke to young people in the community—and at a cost of less than $2,000. It is worth noting that for such a small outlay we have perhaps put off more expensive costs in the future.

One of the most overwhelming things I found in this report was that young people identify issues such as safety and security, freedom from sexual harassment and violence as some of the key issues in their community. This is as important a part of their diet as access to bulk‐billing and medication—two other recommendations contained in the report.

As some participants noted, violence starts early. I only hope that the same political and community will can be applied to addressing violence in all its manifestations, especially violence affecting young Australians in the home, as has been displayed in the recent debate about gun law reform.

Another finding of the report that I found of interest was young people complaining about a lack of space for young people to go to. Interestingly, our society seems more preoccupied with cracking down on young people's access, be it through curfews or other regressive measures—rather than providing some of the simple things that young people are asking for, be it skating ramps, pool halls or just quiet areas where young people can hang out.

Another finding in the report was that young Australians have a real fear of authority figures, security guards, and have a sense that older people are there more so to judge them than to assist them.

The interesting thing about this report is that young people actually provide strategies for countering and coping with some of these problems, be it providing more personalised health centres or youth access centres, improved signage, different people for different jobs, youth magazines and newsletters—better ways of targeting and directing young people.

The strategies in this report also highlight the diversity and creativity among young Australians. I especially like the proposal for `a community built fishfarm run by youth with a pool table which could be profit making'. I thought that was particularly entrepreneurial as well as indicating something that might be rather ecologically sustainable. Why do we not see more of this creativity and positive imagery of young Australians reflected in all decision making bodies, but specifically in the media? I should note that these young Australians had their first encounter with the media during this report and found themselves stereotyped and portrayed in a rather patronising and negative way.

I have noted that the recommendations in this report highlight young people's diversity. It is worth reiterating that young people are not a homogeneous group, especially looking at the age range of 13 to 25 that was covered in this report. Whether they are generation X, generation Y, the Nintendo kids or however we chose to pigeonhole young Australians, certainly the overwhelming feature of this report was a sense of caring and concern for the community.

One particular controversial strategy in this report that I would highlight is the call, overwhelmingly, by young Australians to have condom vending machines not simply in places like schools but in places such as service stations. It was interesting to note that young people feel that they are not being listened to on this issue.

It was particularly revealing in the prime ministerial debates that when John Howard and Paul Keating were asked the question about the availability of condom vending machines in schools, they did not ask what young Australians thought; they simply ruled out this issue. It is worth noting that, not only in this poll but in other surveys and research of young Australians, young people overwhelmingly would like condom vending machines in schools. I challenge this government to take up that controversial issue.

Finally, young Australians said they were not happy with the fact that they have very few outlets to express their fears and their interests, and their concerns generally about community life. I challenge this government to take up an initiative that the Australian Democrats began: an annual youth poll which surveys young people aged 15 to 25 on the issues affecting them. Maybe that would be one way that the coalition government, as well as other political parties or decision making bodies, could more actively involve young Australians in the world around them.

I congratulate Fiona Buchanan and the five consultants who were commissioned to undertake this report. I think their work is of a very fine and high standard. I urge members of this parliament and other people to look at the recommendations and think about how we could more actively involve young people, not simply in the politics of this parliament but in day‐to‐day life generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in the Senate this evening regarding four documents which fundamentally indicate that Australia is lagging behind the world in the sustainable management of forests. At the end of my speech, I will seek leave to table those documents. I am allowing the minister to have time to look at them because, unfortunately, I did not give him time to see them beforehand.

SPEECH.PARA: It is becoming evident that the international community regards the continued logging of primary karri forests in the south‐west of Western Australia as of similar ecological concern to the logging of tropical forests. The documents that I will seek later to table in this place also note that conflict within the community regarding the sustainability of forest management in the south‐west old‐ growth forests is intense. It states that, because of this, certification by an independent organisation to genuinely ascertain sustainability is warranted before any approach other than a precautionary one is legitimate in terms of management of the south‐west forests of Western Australia.

The documents comprise the correspondence between the government of the Netherlands and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management regarding the use of Western Australian karri in hydraulic engineering, namely as canal liners, in the Netherlands. Document No. 1 is a letter dated 12 April 1996 to Dr Syd Shea, Executive Director of the Western Australian Department of CALM, from a B. de Jong of the Dutch Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management.

The second document is the substance to which this letter relates. It is titled Research into sustainable Karri forest management and potential use of Karri timber in hydraulic engineering, by the Directorate General of Public Works and Water Management, Roads and Hydraulic Engineering Division, the Netherlands. The third is a letter from the Wageningen University of Agriculture to the Dutch water management authorities supporting the methodology and thoroughness of the Dutch study. The fourth is a background paper relevant to both, an article by M. C. Calver et al from the periodical Australian Forestry, volume 59 No. 1, titled `Science, principles and forest management: a response to Abbott and Christensen'.

The Dutch embarked upon their study of the sustainability of karri forest management approximately five years ago out of a concern not directly related to karri. Previously, the Dutch water authorities had used the tropical hardwoods azobe and basralocus for their hydraulic engineering in wet environments in the Netherlands. Document two states:
In response to world‐wide concern about the detrimental environmental and ecological effects of tropical deforestation and forest degradation . . .

In 1993 the government of the Netherlands drew together a world‐renowned tropical timber covenant that would ensure that only timber produced in a sustainable way would be imported into the country as of the year 2000. Their research indicated that the traditional woods azobe and basralocus could not reliably be said to be produced sustainably.

Importantly, a key tenet of the 1993 Tropical Timber Covenant was that `logging primary forests'—those which show no signs of serious anthropogenic disturbance, have high biodiversity and no change in original composition—`is arbitrarily not sustainable'. What we call old‐growth or virgin forests are the ones that they believe are arbitrarily nonsustainable.

Secondly, the Dutch policy states that the logging of conversion forests is not sustainable, either. That is where wood comes from forests that have been felled to make way for other land uses, including regrowth forests on what was previously old growth. These points are based on the elementary understanding that old‐growth forests cannot be returned to their former complexity under the current logging regimes of CALM. Single species, uniform age trees, usually of non‐indigenous species, planted in rows in place of a thriving, self‐supporting, dynamic old‐growth ecosystem, does not equal ecologically sustainable forestry. Even in terms of logging rotation, when trees replanted in place of 400‐year‐old trees are felled between 40 and 100 years, that forest never returns to its original majestic state.

As the turning of dynamic old‐growth forest ecosystems into monoculture plantations and the logging of previously virtually untouched forests are both linchpins of Western Australian forest management, it is easy to see why karri forest logging failed the Dutch test. The Dutch documents go on to spell out what makes policy for sustainable forest management. It has three tiers relating to ecological concerns, socioeconomic aspects and socio‐cultural issues.

The ecologically directed component states that forest policy should be `aimed at safeguarding the sustainability of ecological processes, regulatory environmental functions and the ecological condition of all forest functions.' This means protecting the size and quality of forest ecosystems, maintaining the forest's capacity for natural regeneration and its function as a hydrological or orological screen for its surroundings, and protecting threatened species.

With a national forest policy that has not seen one hectare of old-growth forest protected securely and which has been totally ineffective in stopping export woodchipping from chewing up our precious ancient karri, jarrah and mountain ash, it is clear how far we are from the mark as far as the Dutch are concerned. The final decision, as indicated in these documents, is that the terms for using karri timber for Dutch hydraulic engineering purposes as per the 1993 sustainability agreement are these:
Only karri timber from the existing areas of sustainably managed production forest is allowed.

In other words, that means timber from plantations and agro‐forests. Specifically, this item does not include karri timber from primary forests, conversion forests, national parks and conservation reserve areas. Hence, all areas of regrowth forest grown on top of what was previously old growth have rightly been described by the Dutch as being unsustainable methods of forest management in terms of the broad and sensible issues of biodiversity, greenhouse, water catchment and habitat functions of the original forest.

To prove that karri is extracted from sustainably managed production forests, it has to be certified by an independent organisation. The WA department of CALM's assertions as to its so-called world‐class sustainable forestry clearly do not cut it internationally. The Dutch believe that an international audit is warranted.

The documents also note with concern that more than 50 per cent of the globally unique primary karri forest will be transformed into production forest under business as usual principles; that is, we will continue to be logging unsustainably because, as has already been stated, conversion forests do not constitute sustainable forestry. More pointedly, they state that, if things continue, only 40,000 hectares of this primary karri forest will remain in the world.

Overarching all of this is a pervasive concern about the lack of knowledge of the effect of present forest management policy on the ecological values of the karri forests. The precautionary approach is not being honoured. This effect will become increasingly clear after monitoring on the basis of the stability of the biodiversity pool; the effectiveness of buffer zones; the effectiveness of disease control measures, such as the control of dieback; how burning policy compares with true natural fire frequencies; how timber production affects ground water levels and salination; and what current forest management means for climate change. These issues need to be monitored on a true ecological time scale that extends well beyond the few months or years usually devoted to such monitoring programs.

Biodiversity works on a time scale of thousands of years while climate change works on a time scale of decades. We cannot ascertain changes to it in a forest management lunchtime. The precautionary approach is more essential than ever at this time in history.

The Dutch decision to reject south-west karri on the basis of its unsustainability is a development in international affairs that will have far-reaching ramifications for forestry management in Australia. This government can no longer hide its head in the sand from the truth of its environmental recklessness in our precious forests. We must radically rethink our approach to the management of our environment not only in the forests but across the whole spectrum of our day-to-day life.

I seek leave to table these documents in the Senate to put on the public record the enormous risk we are taking in continuing down our current path. International governments are now saying what the community has been saying for years. It is now this government's job to listen.
Leave granted.
