QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones, Sen Gerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the launch by the Minister on 16 April 1996 of a new logo for the Australian Tourism Commission (a kangaroo bounding across a red sun and blue waves):
(1) What were the: (a) direct: and (b) indirect costs of the Commission changing its logo.
(2) What market research was carried out to justify the change in the Commission's logo.
(3) What was the total cost of the research.
(4) If carried out by a private firm, which firm conducted the research.
(5) Were tenders called for the commission of this research.
(6) What were the recommendations of the market research study.
(7) Given the Minister's statement on 16 April 1996 that `Australia has one of the most powerful brand names in the world', what extra tourism will result from the logo change.
(8) When was the Commission's previous logo introduced.
(9) What was the cost of disposing of stationery, signs, etc, bearing the outdated logo.
(10) Why was the sum spent on the logo change not spent directly on promoting tourism.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The direct cost of the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) changing its corporate logo was $31,750. This included design, artwork and the production of a style manual with guidelines for use.
(b) Some indirect costs are involved with the printing of new stationery but old stationery is being fully used before new stationery is introduced.

(2) The decision to change the Commission's corporate logo was based on the implementation of the Brand Australia campaign. This included development of the Brand Australia logo on which the corporate logo is based. Brand Australia research indicated a significant change in consumer tastes and perceptions of Australia since the introduction of the previous logo.
(3) The total Brand Australia campaign research cost $69,200. The corporate logo change was based on this research and no additional research cost was incurred.
(4) Brand Australia research was carried out by the following firms: The Research Business (UK); Joanne Gordon Research (USA); Infoplan (Japan); Asia Market Intelligence Ltd (Korea).

(5) The Brand Australia logo research was an extension of the Advertising Strategy research and Concept Development research that had been conducted previously in 8 major markets (a tendering process was used for this research in 1994). The logo research was considered to be an addendum to the overall creative concepts that were being tested in order to help develop campaigns that would most effectively market Australia to the international traveller.
(6) The kangaroo was seen as an important identifying symbol and the need for vivid colours was highlighted to raise consumer awareness.

As noted above, the corporate logo is an extension of Brand Australia and the design combines dynamism and aesthetic appeal. The Commission considers the use of bright colours creates a vibrant montage suggestive of the youthfulness, welcome, fun, style and panache that characterise Australia.

(7) By creating a unified identity between the Brand Australia and the corporate logos, the Australian Tourist Commission is aiming to attract 14 million visitors over the next three years. This will equate to export earnings over three years of at least $27.3 billion, based on current average visitor expenditure of $1,950 per visitor.
(8) The Australian Tourist Commission's previous logo was introduced in 1982‐83.

(9) No stationery bearing the previous logo will be discarded as stocks were run down over the previous year. There will be some costs as signage is progressively replaced in the Commission's overseas offices. However, these are not expected to be significant.

(10) The sum spent changing the logo has been used to promote tourism by linking the corporate logo to Brand Australia to provide an instantly recognisable Australian identity in the international market place.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Bourne

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 8 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Australian Folk Trust be ceasing operations at the end of 1995 due to the absence of Government funding.
(2) On what basis was the trust's most recent application for funding rejected by the Australian Foundation for Culture and the Humanities.
(3) Did the Minister initially advise the trust that funding was obtainable from the foundation; if so, why.
(4) How will the Government ensure the continued operations of the trust in keeping with the important cultural role they play and as identified in `Creative Nation'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that the Director of the Australian Folk Trust advised the previous Minister in a letter dated 6 October 1995 that the Trust would cease operations at the end of 1995 due to lack of funds. However, I am further advised that the Trust has not formally disbanded.
(2) The Trust lodged an Expression of Interest for support under the Australia Foundation's program `The Australian Experience', advertised on 19 August 1995.
The criteria for Foundation investment are set out in the brochure which accompanied the program (and to which all potential applicants were referred) as follows:

PARA.TAB: `[Proposals are sought] which provide wide public access using innovative communication techniques, have national significance and show a high level of creativity and imagination.
Contribution to an understanding of our country and its future Projects must clearly further the Foundation's aim to "extend Australians' understanding of their own country and its future."
Partnerships

In determining which projects to support, the Foundation will take into account the make up of the partnership team. Partnerships could include cultural and educational institutions, other government agencies (either Federal, State or Local) and community groups. A lead agency must be nominated.
Access
Elements of the project must be widely publicly accessible and should explore innovative ways of disseminating its activities to the public.
Profit Making

The Foundation is supportive of projects which are clearly marketable and will not exclude projects designed to make financial returns. It is unlikely, however, that a team which does not have public institution involvement would attract a high funding priority from the Foundation.
Support from other Commonwealth programs
A project's eligibility for support under other Commonwealth programs will be taken into consideration by the selection panel.'

ANSWER.PARA: The Projects Subcommittee of the Foundation determined that other Expressions of Interest satisfied these criteria to a greater extent than the Expression of Interest of the Australian Folk Trust. It also noted that the Trust was eligible to apply to the Australia Council's Performing Arts Board and Community Cultural Development Board for funding for projects which met those Boards' guidelines and priorities.
(3) I did not advise the Trust that funding was available from the Foundation.

(4) The Government has made no commitment to ensuring the continued existence of the Australian Folk Trust. The Australia Foundation has supported applications from the National Folk Festival and the Queensland Folk Federation in the context of the Australian Experience program. It has also been involved in discussions with the Victorian Folklife Association and oral historians involved with the National Library's Oral History Unit.

The Australian Folk Trust is eligible to apply for assistance under the Foundation's program `The Australian Experience 1996'. This program has eight sub‐programs, and the Trust could potentially apply for funding under a number of these, for example the Oral History and Folklife program for which applications close in September. The Trust may also apply for assistance through any other appropriate Commonwealth program, including programs offered by the Australia Council, for projects which meet the appropriate criteria.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Coalition of Australian Participating Organisations of Women

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) What is the purpose of the group `Capow', which is funded through the Office of the Status of Women.
(2) How long has this group been in operation.
(3) What is the total of all funding received by this group (please list individual grants).
(4) For what purposes was `Capow' granted these various amounts of funding.
(5) What is the date of the latest update of the directory of women's organisations that `Capow' was to initiate.
(6) What steps did `Capow' take to collect and collate resolutions from Australian women for the Beijing Conference of Women, held in September 1995.
(7) What was the purpose of the `Capow' delegation at the United Nations (UN) pre‐Beijing Conference of Women in New York in February 1995.
(8) How many were in the delegation to: (a) New York; and (b) Beijing.
(9) On what agenda items did `Capow' make comment at these conferences and what were those comments.
(10) Is there a peak body of Australian women recognised by the Government; if so, what is its name.
(11) What has been the cost to date of organising a peak body of Australian women.
(12) Has there been a feasibility study to find out the necessity of a peak body of Australian women; if so, who carried out this feasibility study.
(13) What was the cost of the feasibility study.
(14) Was the feasibility study put out to tender; if so, what tenders were received; if not what criteria were used to select the particular company to carry out the feasibility study.
(15) What are the names of all members of the steering committee concerned with the setting up of a peak body of Australian women.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) CAPOW (the Coalition of Australian Participating Organisations of Women) is one of 22 national women's organisations which receive funding from the National Agenda for Women Grants Program which is administered by the Office of the Status of Women. It was established as a loose coalition of women's organisations to facilitate networking amongst non‐Government women's organisations. CAPOW also receives subscriptions from its member organisations.
(2) CAPOW has been in operation since 1993.
(3) CAPOW has received a total of $233,000 in funding from OSW's grants programs as follows:
1992‐93: $21,000—project funding
1993‐94: $60,000—operational funding
1994‐95: $45,000—operational funding
1995‐96: $95,000—operational funding *
* This level of funding was partly in response to the key role played by CAPOW in networking with NGOs prior to the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women held in Beijing in September 1995.
In addition, CAPOW received $12,000 as an ad hoc grant in 1994‐95.

(4) In 1992‐93 project funding was allocated to CAPOW to help establish the organisation. Funding in subsequent years was allocated as operational funding to assist with the administrative costs associated with running the national office.
CAPOW received $12,000 as an ad hoc grant in 1994‐95 to administer the consultancy of the Feasibility Study into the Establishment of a Peak Women's Organisation.

(5) The establishment of a database of women's organisations formed part of CAPOW's original workplan. The database exists and is updated on a regular basis. CAPOW makes information from the database available upon request. For the date of the latest update Senator Calvert would need to contact CAPOW directly.
(6) As far as OSW is aware, CAPOW did not collect `resolutions' from Australian women for the Beijing Conference.

However it undertook a two year plan of activities in the lead up to the Beijing Conference, including holding a national conference and a series of one day forums which resulted in the compilation of information from Australian women on the issues to be discussed at the Beijing Conference.
In addition CAPOW provided information and support to Australian women and organisations on how to get to Beijing and how to run workshops to enhance women's participation in the conference.
(7) OSW understands that there was no CAPOW delegation per se to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) 39—the pre‐Beijing Conference of Women in New York in February 1995.

(8) OSW understands that there was no CAPOW delegation to either New York or Beijing. One CAPOW representative attended CSW39 paid for out of CAPOW's grant allocation under the National Agenda for Women Grants Program administered by OSW and one representative attended the Beijing Conference. Many other NGOs were present at both forums, some of whom were also members of CAPOW.
The Australian Government delegation to (a) New York comprised 14 representatives. The NGO representative on the delegation was Ms Peg McEntee from the Catholic Women's League, Australia.

The Australian Government delegation to (b) Beijing comprised sixteen Government representatives. In addition there were eleven advisers; three of whom were from the NGO community as follows: Dr Tricia Szirom—YWCA; Ms Irene Pneumatikos—Association of Non‐English Speaking Background Women of Australia; and Ms Janet Hunt—Australian Council for Overseas Aid.
(9) OSW is not in a position to respond to this question. Senator Calvert would need to contact CAPOW directly.
(10) No. Although there are a few organisations which purport to being the peak body for women's organisations, these are not recognised as such by a majority of national women's organisations.
(11) See response to part (13)
(12) There has been a study entitled the Feasibility Study into the Establishment of a Peak Women's Organisation.

The Government set up a Steering Committee comprising representatives from women's NGOs and one OSW representative for accountability purposes to oversee the project. A firm of consultants, Wordmap Pty Ltd, were contracted to undertake the feasibility study. The feasibility study was administered by CAPOW.
(13) The total cost to the Government of the feasibility study was $72,326. This was made up of:
$49,500 to the consultants for carrying out the study;
An additional $7,500 to the consultants to undertake a series of workshops following release of the consultants' interim report;
OSW also paid for the consultants' travel to additional consultations at a cost of $3,326; and
$12,000 to CAPOW as an ad hoc grant to administer the consultancy.
(14) The Feasibility Study into the Establishment of a Peak Women's Organisation was put out to selective tender. The original consultant's brief is attached.
OSW is unable to supply the names of the tenderers due to commercial‐in‐confidence obligations.

(15) The Steering Committee comprised: Eileen Pittaway; Susan Brennan; Margaret Cooper; Jan Darlington; Gwen Gray; Betty Johnson; Gwen Roderick; Irene Pneumatikos; Jane Scarlett; Katrina Harrison—OSW; Ex officio—CAPOW; Sheila Hill—Committee Secretary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Kernot

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 27 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What details can be provided of:

(a) Commonwealth expenditure into research projects or the number of surveys currently underway that are designed to estimate the breeding habits of various fish species within the exclusive economic zone;
(b) any joint research fisheries projects with industry or the State Government of New South Wales; and
(c) the number of studies undertaken by the Commonwealth to establish total allowable catches for various fish species in the past 5 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Minister for Resources and Energy, I have portfolio responsibility for fisheries research and development and I am able to provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (a) With reference to fisheries resources in marine waters within the outer limit of Australia's exclusive economic zone, the Commonwealth's Fisheries Research and Development Corporation (FRDC) has been able to identify 80 current research projects funded by it in which issues surrounding the breeding habits of fish species constitute some component. The sum of the total original budgets of these projects comes to some $18.4m, with funds being drawn from allocations over a number of financial years. It is not possible to accurately earmark a proportion of this amount against the components related to breeding habits. The CSIRO Division of Fisheries has estimated that, during 1995-96, it will have spent, from CSIRO funds, amounts of $0.4m, $0.4m and $0.9m respectively on pertinent research projects in the southern bluefin tuna (SBT) fishery, south east fishery (SEF) and northern fisheries. A small number of current projects focusing on breeding habits are receiving funding from the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) Research Fund or the Torres Strait Research and Monitoring Program (TSRMP). The total expenditure on these projects is to be under $0.2m.

(b) FRDC has been able to identify 42 current research projects funded by it which are being commissioned or undertaken by the New South Wales Government, the New South Wales fishing industry or both. The sum of the total original budgets of these projects comes to some $8.6m, with funds being drawn from allocations over a number of financial years. CSIRO Division of Fisheries has advised that it is currently involved in cooperative research with New South Wales Fisheries and the New South Wales fishing industry on gemfish and the SEF ecosystem habitat. Total CSIRO expenditure on these projects is of the order of $1m per annum.

(c) From research projects funded by it which have either been completed during the past 5 years or are still underway, FRDC has been able to identify 107 which could have been or could be used to assist in the establishment of a total allowable catch (TAC). A number of these research projects have been carried out by the CSIRO Division of Fisheries, which has advised that, during the past 5 years, it has undertaken 9 studies on SBT, 1 on yellowfin tuna, 6 on the SEF (orange roughy, blue grenadier and sharks) and 8 on northern fisheries (finfish, prawns, lobsters, trochus and beche-de-mer), each for the purpose of establishing a TAC.

AFMA has identified 17 fishery assessment projects which it has funded from its AFMA Research Fund during the past 5 years. Another 2 stock assessment projects with funding from the same source are currently underway, as well as 2 relating to Torres Strait fisheries which are being funded from the TSRMP.

In the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Bureau of Resource Sciences produces annual resource assessments of Commonwealth-managed fisheries. These are published under the title Fishery Status Reports, the most recent issue of which refers to 1994.
